1.verse: My name is Jeremiah. I am a priest, and my father Hilkiah and everyone else in my family are from Anathoth in the territory of the Benjamin tribe. This book contains the things that the LORD told me to say.

2.verse: The LORD first spoke to me in the thirteenth year that Josiah was king of Judah,

3.verse: and he continued to speak to me during the rule of Josiah’s son Jehoiakim. The last time the LORD spoke to me was in the fifth month of the eleventh year that Josiah’s son Zedekiah was king. That was also when the people of Jerusalem were taken away as prisoners.

4.verse: The LORD Chooses Jeremiah - The LORD said:

5.verse: “Jeremiah, I am your Creator, and before you were born, I chose you to speak for me to the nations.”

6.verse: I replied, “I’m not a good speaker, LORD, and I’m too young.”

7.verse: “Don’t say you’re too young,” the LORD answered. “If I tell you to go and speak to someone, then go! And when I tell you what to say, don’t leave out a word!

8.verse: I promise to be with you and keep you safe, so don’t be afraid.”

9.verse: The LORD reached out his hand, then he touched my mouth and said, “I am giving you the words to say,

10.verse: and I am sending you with authority to speak to the nations for me. You will tell them of doom and destruction, and of rising and rebuilding again.”

11.verse: The LORD showed me something in a vision. Then he asked, “What do you see, Jeremiah?” I answered, “A branch of almonds that ripen early.”

12.verse: “That’s right,” the LORD replied, “and I always rise early to keep a promise.”

13.verse: Then the LORD showed me something else and asked, “What do you see now?” I answered, “I see a pot of boiling water in the north, and it’s about to spill out toward us.”

14.verse: The LORD said: I will pour out destruction all over the land.

15.verse: Just watch while I send for the kings of the north. They will attack and capture Jerusalem and other towns, then set up their thrones at the gates of Jerusalem.

16.verse: I will punish my people, because they are guilty of turning from me to worship idols.

17.verse: Jeremiah, get ready! Go and tell the people what I command you to say. Don’t be frightened by them, or I will make you terrified while they watch.

18.verse: My power will make you strong like a fortress or a column of iron or a wall of bronze. You will oppose all of Judah, including its kings and leaders, its priests and people.

19.verse: They will fight back, but they won’t win. I, the LORD, give my word— I won’t let them harm you.

1.verse: Israel’s Unfaithfulness - The LORD told me

2.verse: to go to Jerusalem and tell everyone that he had said: When you were my young bride, you loved me and followed me through the barren desert.

3.verse: You belonged to me alone, like the first part of the harvest, and I severely punished those who mistreated you.

4.verse: Listen, people of Israel,

5.verse: and I, the LORD, will speak. I was never unfair to your ancestors, but they left me and became worthless by following worthless idols.

6.verse: Your ancestors refused to ask for my help, though I had rescued them from Egypt and led them through a treacherous, barren desert, where no one lives or dares to travel.

7.verse: I brought you here to my land, where food is abundant, but you made my land filthy with your sins.

8.verse: The priests who teach my laws don’t care to know me. Your leaders rebel against me; your prophets give messages from Baal and worship false gods.

9.verse: The LORD Accuses His People - I will take you to court and accuse you and your descendants

10.verse: of a crime that no nation has ever committed before. Just ask anyone, anywhere, from the eastern deserts to the islands in the west.

11.verse: You will find that no nation has ever abandoned its gods even though they were false. I am the true and glorious God, but you have rejected me to worship idols.

12.verse: Tell the heavens to tremble with fear!

13.verse: You, my people, have sinned in two ways— you have rejected me, the source of life-giving water, and you’ve tried to collect water in cracked and leaking pits dug in the ground.

14.verse: People of Israel, you weren’t born slaves; you were captured in war.

15.verse: Enemies roared like lions and destroyed your land; towns lie burned and empty.

16.verse: Soldiers from the Egyptian towns of Memphis and Tahpanhes have cracked your skulls.

17.verse: It’s all your own fault! You stopped following me, the LORD your God,

18.verse: and you trusted the power of Egypt and Assyria.

19.verse: Your own sins will punish you, because it was a bitter mistake for you to reject me without fear of punishment. I, the LORD All-Powerful, have spoken.

20.verse: Long ago you left me and broke all ties between us, refusing to be my servant. Now you worship other gods by having sex on hilltops or in the shade of large trees.

21.verse: You were a choice grapevine, but now you produce nothing but small, rotten grapes.

22.verse: Israel Is Stained with Guilt - The LORD said: People of Israel, you are stained with guilt, and no soap or bleach can wash it away.

23.verse: You deny your sins and say, “We aren’t unclean. We haven’t worshiped Baal.” But think about what you do in Hinnom Valley. And you run back and forth like young camels, as you rush to worship one idol after another.

24.verse: You are a female donkey sniffing the desert air, wanting to mate with just anyone. You are an easy catch!

25.verse: Your shoes are worn out, and your throat is parched from running here and there to worship foreign gods. “Stop!” I shouted, but you replied, “No! I love those gods too much.”

26.verse: You and your leaders are more disgraceful than thieves— you and your kings, your priests and prophets

27.verse: worship stone idols and sacred poles as if they had created you and had given you life. You have rejected me, but when you’re in trouble, you cry to me for help.

28.verse: Go cry to the gods you made! There should be enough of them to save you, because Judah has as many gods as it has towns.

29.verse: Israel Rebels against the LORD - The LORD said to Israel: You accuse me of not saving you, but I say you have rebelled.

30.verse: I tried punishing you, but you refused to come back to me, and like fierce lions you killed my prophets.

31.verse: Now listen to what I say! Did I abandon you in the desert or surround you with darkness? You are my people, yet you have told me, “We’ll do what we want, and we refuse to worship you!”

32.verse: A bride could not forget to wear her jewelry to her wedding, but you have forgotten me day after day.

33.verse: You are so clever at finding lovers that you could give lessons to a prostitute.

34.verse: You killed innocent people for no reason at all. And even though their blood can be seen on your clothes,

35.verse: you claim to be innocent, and you want me to stop being angry with you. So I’ll take you to court, and we’ll see who is right.

36.verse: When Assyria let you down, you ran to Egypt, but you’ll find no help there,

37.verse: and you will leave in great sadness. I won’t let you find help from those you trust.

1.verse: Sin and Shame - The LORD said to the people of Israel: If a divorced woman marries, can her first husband ever marry her again? No, because this would pollute the land. But you have more gods than a prostitute has lovers. Why should I take you back?

2.verse: Just try to find one hilltop where you haven’t gone to worship other gods by having sex. You sat beside the road like a robber in ambush, except you offered yourself to every passerby. Your sins of unfaithfulness have polluted the land.

3.verse: So I, the LORD, refused to let the spring rains fall. But just like a prostitute, you still have no shame for what you have done.

4.verse: You call me your father or your long-lost friend;

5.verse: you beg me to stop being angry, but you won’t stop sinning.

6.verse: The LORD Asks Israel To Come Back to Him - When Josiah was king, the LORD said: Jeremiah, the kingdom of Israel was like an unfaithful wife who became a prostitute on the hilltops and in the shade of large trees.

7.verse: I knew that the kingdom of Israel had been unfaithful and committed many sins, yet I still hoped she might come back to me. But she didn’t, so I divorced her and sent her away. Her sister, the kingdom of Judah, saw what happened, but she wasn’t worried in the least, and I watched her become unfaithful like her sister.

8.verse: I knew that the kingdom of Israel had been unfaithful and committed many sins, yet I still hoped she might come back to me. But she didn’t, so I divorced her and sent her away. Her sister, the kingdom of Judah, saw what happened, but she wasn’t worried in the least, and I watched her become unfaithful like her sister.

9.verse: The kingdom of Judah wasn’t sorry for being a prostitute, and she didn’t care that she had made both herself and the land unclean by worshiping idols of stone and wood.

10.verse: And worst of all, the people of Judah pretended to come back to me.

11.verse: Even the people of Israel were honest enough not to pretend.

12.verse: Jeremiah, shout toward the north: Israel, I am your LORD— come back to me! You were unfaithful and made me furious, but I am merciful, and so I will forgive you.

13.verse: Just admit that you rebelled and worshiped foreign gods under large trees everywhere.

14.verse: You are unfaithful children, but you belong to me. Come home! I’ll take one or two of you from each town and clan and bring you to Zion.

15.verse: Then I’ll appoint wise rulers who will obey me, and they will care for you like shepherds.

16.verse: You will increase in numbers, and there will be no need to remember the sacred chest or to make a new one.

17.verse: The whole city of Jerusalem will be my throne. All nations will come here to worship me, and they will no longer follow their stubborn, evil hearts.

18.verse: Then, in countries to the north, you people of Judah and Israel will be reunited, and you will return to the land I gave your ancestors.

19.verse: I have always wanted to treat you as my children and give you the best land, the most beautiful on earth. I wanted you to call me “Father” and not turn from me.

20.verse: But instead, you are like a wife who broke her wedding vows. You have been unfaithful to me. I, the LORD, have spoken.

21.verse: The People Confess Their Sins - The LORD said: Listen to the noise on the hilltops! It’s the people of Israel, weeping and begging me to answer their prayers. They forgot about me and chose the wrong path.

22.verse: I will tell them, “Come back, and I will cure you of your unfaithfulness.” They will answer, “We will come back, because you are the LORD our God.

23.verse: On hilltops, we worshiped idols and made loud noises, but it was all for nothing— only you can save us.

24.verse: Since the days of our ancestors when our nation was young, that shameful god Baal has taken our crops and livestock, our sons and daughters.

25.verse: We have rebelled against you just like our ancestors, and we are ashamed of our sins.”

1.verse: How Israel Can Return to the LORD - The LORD said: Israel, if you really want to come back to me, get rid of those disgusting idols.

2.verse: Make promises only in my name, and do what you promise! Then all nations will praise me, and I will bless them.

3.verse: People of Jerusalem and Judah, don’t be so stubborn! Your hearts have become hard, like unplowed ground where thornbushes grow.

4.verse: With all your hearts, keep the agreement I made with you. But if you are stubborn and keep on sinning, my anger will burn like a fire that cannot be put out.

5.verse: Disaster Is Coming - The LORD said: “Sound the trumpets, my people. Warn the people of Judah, ‘Run for your lives!

6.verse: Head for Jerusalem or another walled town!' “Jeremiah, tell them I’m sending disaster from the north.

7.verse: An army will come out, like a lion from its den. It will destroy nations and leave your towns empty and in ruins.”

8.verse: Then I said to the people of Israel, “Put on sackcloth! Mourn and cry out, ‘The LORD is still angry with us.’”

9.verse: The LORD said, “When all this happens, the king and his officials, the prophets and the priests will be shocked and terrified.”

10.verse: I said, “You are the LORD God. So why have you fooled everyone, especially the people of Jerusalem? Why did you promise peace, when a knife is at our throats?”

11.verse: The Coming Disaster - When disaster comes, the LORD will tell you people of Jerusalem, “I am sending a windstorm from the desert— not a welcome breeze. And it will sweep you away as punishment for your sins.

12.verse: The Coming Disaster - When disaster comes, the LORD will tell you people of Jerusalem, “I am sending a windstorm from the desert— not a welcome breeze. And it will sweep you away as punishment for your sins.

13.verse: Look! The enemy army swoops down like an eagle; their cavalry and chariots race faster than storm clouds blown by the wind.” Then you will answer, “We are doomed!”

14.verse: But Jerusalem, there is still time for you to be saved. Wash the evil from your hearts and stop making sinful plans,

15.verse: before a message of disaster arrives from the hills of Ephraim and the town of Dan.

16.verse: The LORD said, “Tell the nations that my people have rebelled against me. And so an army will come from far away to surround Jerusalem and the towns of Judah. I, the LORD, have spoken.

17.verse: The LORD said, “Tell the nations that my people have rebelled against me. And so an army will come from far away to surround Jerusalem and the towns of Judah. I, the LORD, have spoken.

18.verse: “People of Judah, your hearts will be in pain, but it’s your own fault that you will be punished.”

19.verse: Jeremiah’s Vision of the Coming Punishment - I can’t stand the pain! My heart pounds, as I twist and turn in agony. I hear the signal trumpet and the battle cry of the enemy, and I cannot be silent.

20.verse: I see the enemy defeating us time after time, leaving everything in ruins. Even my own home is destroyed in a moment.

21.verse: How long will I see enemy flags and hear their trumpets?

22.verse: I heard the LORD say, “My people ignore me. They are foolish children who do not understand that they will be punished. All they know is how to sin.”

23.verse: After this, I looked around. The earth was barren, with no form of life. The sun, moon, and stars had disappeared.

24.verse: The mountains were shaking;

25.verse: no people could be seen, and all the birds had flown away.

26.verse: Farmland had become a desert, and towns were in ruins. The LORD’s fierce anger had done all of this.

27.verse: The Death of Jerusalem - The LORD said: I have made my decision, and I won’t change my mind. This land will be destroyed, although not completely. The sky will turn dark, and the earth will mourn.

28.verse: The Death of Jerusalem - The LORD said: I have made my decision, and I won’t change my mind. This land will be destroyed, although not completely. The sky will turn dark, and the earth will mourn.

29.verse: Enemy cavalry and archers shout their battle cry. People run for their lives and try to find safety among trees and rocks. Every town is empty.

30.verse: Jerusalem, your land has been wiped out. But you act like a prostitute and try to win back your lovers, who now hate you. You can put on a red dress, gold jewelry, and eye shadow, but it’s no use— your lovers are out to kill you!

31.verse: I heard groaning and crying. Was it a woman giving birth to her first child? No, it was Jerusalem. She was gasping for breath and begging for help. “I’m dying!” she said. “They have murdered me.”

1.verse: Is Anyone Honest and Faithful? - The LORD said to me: “Search Jerusalem for honest people who try to be faithful. If you can find even one, I’ll forgive the whole city.

2.verse: Everyone breaks promises made in my name.”

3.verse: I answered, “I know that you look for truth. You punished your people for their lies, but in spite of the pain, they became more stubborn and refused to turn back to you.”

4.verse: Then I thought to myself, “These common people act like fools, and they have never learned what the LORD their God demands of them.

5.verse: I’ll go and talk to the leaders. They know what God demands.” But even they had decided not to obey the LORD.

6.verse: The people have rebelled and rejected the LORD too many times. So enemies will attack like lions from the forest or wolves from the desert. Those enemies will watch the towns of Judah, and like leopards they will tear to pieces whoever goes outside.

7.verse: Enemies Will Punish Judah - The LORD said: People of Judah, how can I forgive you? I gave you everything, but you abandoned me and worshiped idols. You men go to prostitutes and are unfaithful to your wives.

8.verse: You are no better than animals, and you always want sex with someone else’s wife.

9.verse: Why shouldn’t I punish the people of Judah?

10.verse: I will tell their enemies, “Go through my vineyard. Don’t destroy the vines, but cut off the branches, because they are the people who don’t belong to me.”

11.verse: In every way, Judah and Israel have been unfaithful to me.

12.verse: Their prophets lie and say, “The LORD won’t punish us. We will have peace and plenty of food.”

13.verse: They tell these lies in my name, so now they will be killed in war or starve to death.

14.verse: I am the LORD God All-Powerful. Jeremiah, I will tell you exactly what to say. Your words will be a fire; Israel and Judah will be the fuel.

15.verse: People of Israel, I have made my decision. An army from a distant country will attack you. I’ve chosen an ancient nation, and you won’t understand their language.

16.verse: All of them are warriors, and their arrows bring death.

17.verse: This nation will eat your crops and livestock; they will leave no fruit on your vines or trees. And although you feel safe behind thick walls, your towns will be destroyed and your children killed.

18.verse: Israel Refused To Worship the LORD - The LORD said: Jeremiah, the enemy army won’t kill everyone in Judah.

19.verse: And the people who survive will ask, “Why did the LORD our God do such terrible things to us?” Then tell them: I am the LORD, but you abandoned me and worshiped other gods in your own land. Now you will be slaves in a foreign country.

20.verse: Tell these things to each other, you people of Judah, you descendants of Jacob.

21.verse: You fools! Why don’t you listen when I speak? Why can’t you understand

22.verse: that you should worship me with fear and trembling? I’m the one who made the shore to hold back the ocean. Waves may crash on the beach, but they can come no farther.

23.verse: You stubborn people have rebelled and turned your backs on me.

24.verse: You refuse to say, “Let’s worship the LORD! He’s the one who sends rain in spring and autumn and gives us a good harvest.”

25.verse: That’s why I cannot bless you!

26.verse: A hunter traps birds and puts them in a cage, but some of you trap humans and make them your slaves.

27.verse: You are evil, and you lie and cheat to make yourselves rich. You are powerful

28.verse: and prosperous, but you refuse to help the poor get the justice they deserve.

29.verse: You need to be punished, and so I will take revenge.

30.verse: Look at the terrible things going on in this country. I am shocked!

31.verse: Prophets give their messages in the name of a false god, my priests don’t want to serve me, and you—my own people— like it this way! But on the day of disaster, where will you turn for help?

1.verse: A Warning for the People of Jerusalem - The LORD said: Run for your lives, people of Benjamin. Get out of Jerusalem. Sound a trumpet in Tekoa and light a signal fire in Beth-Haccherem. Soon you will be struck by disaster from the north.

2.verse: Jerusalem is a lovely pasture, but shepherds will surround it and divide it up,

3.verse: then let their flocks eat all the grass.

4.verse: Kings will tell their troops, “If we reach Jerusalem in the morning, we’ll attack at noon. But if we arrive later,

5.verse: we’ll attack after dark and destroy its fortresses.”

6.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful, and I will command these armies to chop down trees and build a ramp up to the walls of Jerusalem. People of Jerusalem, I must punish you for your injustice.

7.verse: Evil pours from your city like water from a spring. Sounds of violent crimes echo within your walls; victims are everywhere, wounded and dying.

8.verse: Listen to me, you people of Jerusalem and Judah. I will abandon you, and your land will become an empty desert.

9.verse: I will tell your enemies to leave your nation bare like a vine stripped of grapes. I, the LORD All-Powerful, have spoken.

10.verse: Jeremiah’s Anger - I have told the people that you, LORD, will punish them, but they just laugh and refuse to listen.

11.verse: Your anger against Judah flames up inside me, and I can’t hold it in much longer. The LORD’s Anger Will Sweep Everyone Away - The LORD answered:Don’t hold back my anger! Let it sweep away everyone— the children at play and all adults, young and old alike.

12.verse: I’ll punish the people of Judah and give to others their houses and fields, as well as their wives. I, the LORD, have spoken.

13.verse: Everyone is greedy and dishonest, whether poor or rich. Even the prophets and priests cannot be trusted.

14.verse: All they ever offer to my deeply wounded people are empty hopes for peace.

15.verse: They should be ashamed of their disgusting sins, but they don’t even blush. And so, when I punish Judah, they will end up on the ground, dead like everyone else. I, the LORD, have spoken.

16.verse: The People of Judah Rejected God’s Way of Life - The LORD said: My people, when you stood at the crossroads, I told you, “Follow the road your ancestors took, and you will find peace.” But you refused.

17.verse: I also sent prophets to warn you of danger, but when they sounded the alarm, you paid no attention.

18.verse: So I tell all nations on earth, “Watch what I will do!

19.verse: My people ignored me and rejected my laws. They planned to do evil, and now the evil they planned will happen to them.”

20.verse: People of Judah, you bring me incense from Sheba and spices from distant lands. You offer sacrifices of all kinds. But why bother? I hate these gifts of yours!

21.verse: So I will put stumbling blocks in your path, and everyone will die, including parents and children, neighbors and friends.

22.verse: An Army from the North - The LORD said, “Look toward the north, where a powerful nation has prepared for war.

23.verse: Its well-armed troops are cruel and never show mercy. Their galloping horses sound like ocean waves pounding on the shore. This army will attack you, lovely Jerusalem.”

24.verse: Then the people said, “Just hearing about them makes us tremble with fear, and we twist and turn in pain like a woman giving birth.”

25.verse: The LORD said, “Don’t work in your fields or walk along the roads. It’s too dangerous. The enemy is well armed

26.verse: and attacks without warning. So mourn, my people, as though your only child had died. Wear clothes made of sackcloth and roll in the ash pile.”

27.verse: The LORD’s People Must Be Tested - The LORD said: Jeremiah, test my people as though they were metal.

28.verse: And you’ll find they are hard like bronze and iron. They are stubborn rebels, always spreading lies.

29.verse: Silver can be purified in a fiery furnace,

30.verse: but my people are too wicked to be made pure, and so I have rejected them.

1.verse: Jeremiah Speaks in the Temple - The LORD told me to stand by the gate of the temple and to tell the people who were going in that the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, had said: Pay attention, people of Judah! Change your ways and start living right, then I will let you keep on living in your own country.

2.verse: Jeremiah Speaks in the Temple - The LORD told me to stand by the gate of the temple and to tell the people who were going in that the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, had said: Pay attention, people of Judah! Change your ways and start living right, then I will let you keep on living in your own country.

3.verse: Jeremiah Speaks in the Temple - The LORD told me to stand by the gate of the temple and to tell the people who were going in that the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, had said: Pay attention, people of Judah! Change your ways and start living right, then I will let you keep on living in your own country.

4.verse: Don’t fool yourselves! My temple is here in Jerusalem, but that doesn’t mean I will protect you.

5.verse: I will keep you safe only if you change your ways. Be fair and honest with each other.

6.verse: Stop taking advantage of foreigners, orphans, and widows. Don’t kill innocent people. And stop worshiping other gods.

7.verse: Then I will let you enjoy a long life in this land I gave your ancestors.

8.verse: But just look at what is happening! You put your trust in worthless lies.

9.verse: You steal and murder; you lie in court and are unfaithful in marriage. You worship idols and offer incense to Baal, when these gods have never done anything for you.

10.verse: And then you come into my temple and worship me! Do you think I will protect you so that you can go on sinning?

11.verse: You are thieves, and you have made my temple your hideout. But I’ve seen everything you have done.

12.verse: Go to Shiloh, where my sacred tent once stood. Take a look at what I did there. My people Israel sinned, and so I destroyed Shiloh!

13.verse: While you have been sinning, I have been trying to talk to you, but you refuse to listen.

14.verse: Don’t think this temple will protect you. Long ago I told your ancestors to build it and worship me here, but now I have decided to tear it down, just as I destroyed Shiloh.

15.verse: And as for you, people of Judah, I’m going to send you away from my land, just as I sent away the people of Ephraim and the other northern tribes.

16.verse: Punishment for Worshiping Other Gods - Jeremiah, don’t pray for these people! I, the LORD, would refuse to listen.

17.verse: Do you see what the people of Judah are doing in their towns and in the streets of Jerusalem?

18.verse: Children gather firewood, their fathers build fires, and their mothers mix dough to bake bread for the goddess they call the Queen of Heaven. They even offer wine sacrifices to other gods, just to insult me.

19.verse: But they are not only insulting me; they are also insulting themselves by doing these shameful things.

20.verse: And now, I, the LORD All-Powerful, will flood Judah with my fiery anger until nothing is left—no people or animals, no trees or crops.

21.verse: It Is Useless To Offer Sacrifices - The LORD told me to say to the people of Judah: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, but I won’t accept sacrifices from you. So don’t even bother bringing them to me. You might as well just cook the meat for yourselves.

22.verse: At the time I brought your ancestors out of Egypt, I didn’t command them to offer sacrifices to me.

23.verse: Instead, I told them, “If you listen to me and do what I tell you, I will be your God, you will be my people, and all will go well for you.”

24.verse: But your ancestors refused to listen. They were stubborn, and whenever I wanted them to go one way, they always went the other.

25.verse: Ever since your ancestors left Egypt, I have been sending my servants the prophets to speak for me.

26.verse: But you have ignored me and become even more stubborn and sinful than your ancestors ever were!

27.verse: Slaughter Valley - The LORD said: Jeremiah, no matter what you do, the people won’t listen.

28.verse: So you must say to them: People of Judah, I am the LORD your God, but you have refused to obey me, and you didn’t change when I punished you. And now, you no longer even pretend to be faithful to me.

29.verse: Shave your head bald and throw away the hair. Sing a funeral song on top of a barren hill. You people have made me angry, and I have abandoned you.

30.verse: You have disobeyed me by putting your disgusting idols in my temple, and now the temple itself is disgusting to me.

31.verse: At Topheth in Hinnom Valley you have built altars where you kill your children and burn them as sacrifices to other gods. I would never think of telling you to do this.

32.verse: So watch out! Someday that place will no longer be called Topheth or Hinnom Valley. It will be called Slaughter Valley, because you will bury your dead there until you run out of room,

33.verse: and then bodies will lie scattered on the ground. Birds and wild animals will come and eat, and no one will be around to scare them off.

34.verse: When I am finished with your land, there will be deathly silence in the empty ruins of Jerusalem and the towns of Judah—no happy voices, no sounds of parties or wedding celebrations.

1.verse: Then the bones of the dead kings of Judah and their officials will be dug up, along with the bones of the priests, the prophets, and everyone else in Jerusalem

2.verse: who loved and worshiped the sun, moon, and stars. These bones will be scattered and left lying on the ground like trash, where the sun and moon and stars can shine on them.

3.verse: Some of you people of Judah will be left alive, but I will force you to go to foreign countries, and you will wish you were dead. I, the LORD God All-Powerful, have spoken.

4.verse: The People Took the Wrong Road - The LORD said: People of Jerusalem, when you stumble and fall, you get back up, and if you take a wrong road, you turn around and go back.

5.verse: So why do you refuse to come back to me? Why do you hold so tightly to your false gods?

6.verse: I listen carefully, but none of you admit that you’ve done wrong. Without a second thought, you run down the wrong road like cavalry troops charging into battle.

7.verse: Storks, doves, swallows, and thrushes all know when it’s time to fly away for the winter and when to come back. But you, my people, don’t know what I demand.

8.verse: You say, “We are wise because we have the teachings and laws of the LORD.” But I say that your teachers have turned my words into lies!

9.verse: Your wise men have rejected what I say, and so they have no wisdom. Now they will be trapped and put to shame; they won’t know what to do.

10.verse: I’ll give their wives and fields to strangers. Everyone is greedy and dishonest, whether poor or rich. Even the prophets and priests cannot be trusted.

11.verse: All they ever offer to my deeply wounded people are empty hopes for peace.

12.verse: They should be ashamed of their disgusting sins, but they don’t even blush. And so, when I punish Judah, they will end up on the ground, dead like everyone else.

13.verse: I will wipe them out. They are vines without grapes; fig trees without figs or leaves. They have not done a thing that I told them! I, the LORD, have spoken.

14.verse: The People and Their Punishment - The people of Judah say to each other, “What are we waiting for? Let’s run to a town with walls and die there. We rebelled against the LORD, and we were sentenced to die by drinking poison.

15.verse: We had hoped for peace and a time of healing, but all we got was terror.

16.verse: Our enemies have reached the town of Dan in the north, and the snorting of their horses makes us tremble with fear. The enemy will destroy Jerusalem and our entire nation. No one will survive.”

17.verse: “Watch out!” the LORD says. “I’m sending poisonous snakes to attack you, and no one can stop them.”

18.verse: Jeremiah Mourns for His People - I’m burdened with sorrow and feel like giving up.

19.verse: In a foreign land my people are crying. Listen! You’ll hear them say, “Has the LORD deserted Zion? Is he no longer its king?” I hear the LORD reply, “Why did you make me angry by worshiping useless idols?”

20.verse: The people complain, “Spring and summer have come and gone, but still the LORD hasn’t rescued us.”

21.verse: My people are crushed, and so is my heart. I am horrified and mourn.

22.verse: If medicine and doctors may be found in Gilead, why aren’t my people healed?

1.verse: I wish that my eyes were fountains of tears, so I could cry day and night for my people who were killed.

2.verse: I wish I could go into the desert and find a hiding place from all who are treacherous and unfaithful to God.

3.verse: The LORD Answers Jeremiah - The LORD replied: Lies come from the mouths of my people, like arrows from a bow. With each dishonest deed their power increases, and not one of them will admit that I am God.

4.verse: Jeremiah, all your friends and relatives tell lies about you, so don’t trust them.

5.verse: They wear themselves out, always looking for a new way to cheat their friends.

6.verse: Everyone takes advantage of everyone else, and no one will admit that I am God.

7.verse: And so I will purify the hearts of my people just as gold is purified in a furnace. I have no other choice.

8.verse: They say they want peace, but this lie is deadly, like an arrow that strikes when you least expect it.

9.verse: Give me one good reason not to punish them as they deserve. I, the LORD All-Powerful, have spoken.

10.verse: Jeremiah Weeps for His People - I weep for the pastureland in the hill country. It’s so barren and scorched that no one travels there. No cattle can be found there, and birds and wild animals have all disappeared.

11.verse: I heard the LORD reply, “When I am finished, Jerusalem and the towns of Judah will be piles of ruins where only jackals live.”

12.verse: Why the Land Was Destroyed - I said to the LORD, “None of us can understand why the land has become like an uncrossable desert. Won’t you explain why?”

13.verse: The LORD said: I destroyed the land because the people disobeyed me and rejected my laws and teachings.

14.verse: They were stubborn and worshiped Baal, just as their ancestors did.

15.verse: So I, the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, promise them poison to eat and drink.

16.verse: I’ll scatter them in foreign countries that they and their ancestors have never even heard of. Finally, I will send enemy soldiers to kill every last one of them.

17.verse: The Women Who Are Paid To Weep - The LORD All-Powerful said, “Send for the women who are paid to weep at funerals, especially the women who can cry the loudest.”

18.verse: The people answered, “Let them come quickly and cry for us, until our own eyes are flooded with tears.

19.verse: Now those of us on Zion cry, ‘We are ruined! We can’t stand the shame. Our homes have been destroyed, and we must leave our land.'

20.verse: “We ask you women to pay attention to what the LORD says. We will teach you a funeral song that you can teach your daughters and friends:

21.verse: ’We were in our fortress, but death sneaked in through our windows. It even struck down children at play and our strongest young men.'

22.verse: “The LORD has told us the ground will be covered with dead bodies, like stalks of ungathered grain or like manure.”

23.verse: What the LORD Likes Best - The LORD says: Don’t brag about your wisdom or strength or wealth.

24.verse: If you feel you must brag, then have enough sense to brag about worshiping me, the LORD. What I like best is showing kindness, justice, and mercy to everyone on earth.

25.verse: Someday I will punish the nations of Egypt, Edom, Ammon, and Moab, and the tribes of the desert. The men of these nations are circumcised, but they don’t worship me. And it’s the same with you people of Judah. Your bodies are circumcised, but your hearts are unchanged.

26.verse: Someday I will punish the nations of Egypt, Edom, Ammon, and Moab, and the tribes of the desert. The men of these nations are circumcised, but they don’t worship me. And it’s the same with you people of Judah. Your bodies are circumcised, but your hearts are unchanged.

1.verse: The LORD Talks about Idols - The LORD said: Listen to me, you people of Israel.

2.verse: Don’t follow the customs of those nations who become frightened when they see something strange happen in the sky.

3.verse: Their religion is worthless! They chop down a tree, carve the wood into an idol,

4.verse: cover it with silver and gold, and then nail it down so it won’t fall over.

5.verse: An idol is no better than a scarecrow. It can’t speak, and it has to be carried, because it can’t walk. Why worship an idol that can’t help or harm you?

6.verse: Jeremiah Praises the LORD - Our LORD, great and powerful, you alone are God.

7.verse: You are King of the nations. Everyone should worship you. No human anywhere on earth is wiser than you.

8.verse: Idols are worthless, and anyone who worships them is a fool!

9.verse: Idols are made by humans. A carver shapes the wood. A metalworker hammers out a covering of gold from Uphaz or of silver from Tarshish. Then the idol is dressed in blue and purple clothes.

10.verse: You, LORD, are the only true and living God. You will rule for all time. When you are angry the earth shakes, and nations are destroyed.

11.verse: You told me to say that idols did not create the heavens and the earth, and that you, the LORD, will destroy every idol.

12.verse: With your wisdom and power you created the earth and spread out the heavens.

13.verse: The waters in the heavens roar at your command. You make clouds appear— you send the winds from your storehouse and make lightning flash in the rain.

14.verse: People who make idols are so stupid! They will be disappointed, because their false gods are not alive.

15.verse: Idols are merely a joke, and when the time is right, they will be destroyed.

16.verse: But you, Israel’s God, created all things, and you chose Israel to be your very own. Your name is the LORD All-Powerful.

17.verse: Judah Will Be Thrown from Its Land - I said to the people of Judah, “Gather your things; you are surrounded.

18.verse: The LORD said these troubles will lead to your capture, and he will throw you from this land like a rock from a sling.”

19.verse: The people answered, “We are wounded and doomed to die. Why did we say we could stand the pain?

20.verse: Our homes are destroyed; our children are dead. No one is left to help us find shelter.”

21.verse: But I told them, “Our leaders were stupid failures, because they refused to listen to the LORD. And so we’ve been scattered like sheep.

22.verse: “Sounds of destruction rumble from the north like distant thunder. Soon our towns will be ruins where jackals live.”

23.verse: Jeremiah Prays - I know, LORD, that we humans are not in control of our own lives.

24.verse: Correct me, as I deserve, but not in your anger, or I will be dead.

25.verse: Our enemies refuse to admit that you are God or to worship you. They have wiped out our people and left our nation lying in ruins. So get angry and sweep them away!

1.verse: Judah Has Broken the LORD’s Agreement - The LORD God told me to say to the people of Judah and Jerusalem: I, the LORD, am warning you that I will put a curse on anyone who doesn’t keep the agreement I made with Israel. So pay attention to what it says.

2.verse: Judah Has Broken the LORD’s Agreement - The LORD God told me to say to the people of Judah and Jerusalem: I, the LORD, am warning you that I will put a curse on anyone who doesn’t keep the agreement I made with Israel. So pay attention to what it says.

3.verse: Judah Has Broken the LORD’s Agreement - The LORD God told me to say to the people of Judah and Jerusalem: I, the LORD, am warning you that I will put a curse on anyone who doesn’t keep the agreement I made with Israel. So pay attention to what it says.

4.verse: My commands haven’t changed since I brought your ancestors out of Egypt, a nation that seemed like a blazing furnace where iron ore is melted. I told your ancestors that if they obeyed my commands, I would be their God, and they would be my people.

5.verse: Then I did what I had promised and gave them this wonderful land, where you now live. “Yes, LORD,” I replied, “that’s true.”

6.verse: Then the LORD told me to say to everyone on the streets of Jerusalem and in the towns of Judah: Pay attention to the commands in my agreement with you.

7.verse: Ever since I brought your ancestors out of Egypt, I have been telling your people to obey me. But you and your ancestors

8.verse: have always been stubborn. You have refused to listen, and instead you have done whatever your sinful hearts have desired. You have not kept the agreement we made, so I will make you suffer every curse that goes with it.

9.verse: The LORD said to me: Jeremiah, the people of Judah and Jerusalem are plotting against me.

10.verse: They have sinned in the same way their ancestors did, by turning from me and worshiping other gods. The northern kingdom of Israel broke the agreement I made with your ancestors, and now the southern kingdom of Judah has done the same.

11.verse: Here is what I’ve decided to do. I will bring suffering on the people of Judah and Jerusalem, and no one will escape. They will beg me to help, but I won’t listen to their prayers.

12.verse: Then they will offer sacrifices to their other gods and ask them for help. After all, the people of Judah have more gods than towns, and more altars for Baal than there are streets in Jerusalem. But those gods won’t be able to rescue the people of Judah from disaster.

13.verse: Then they will offer sacrifices to their other gods and ask them for help. After all, the people of Judah have more gods than towns, and more altars for Baal than there are streets in Jerusalem. But those gods won’t be able to rescue the people of Judah from disaster.

14.verse: Jeremiah, don’t pray for these people or beg me to rescue them. If you do, I won’t listen, and I certainly won’t listen if they pray!

15.verse: Then the LORD told me to say to the people of Judah: You are my chosen people, but you have no right to be here in my temple, doing such terrible things. The sacrifices you offer me won’t protect you from disaster, so stop celebrating.

16.verse: Once you were like an olive tree covered with fruit. But soon I will send a noisy mob to break off your branches and set you on fire.

17.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful. You people of Judah were like a tree that I had planted, but you have made me angry by offering sacrifices to Baal, just as the northern kingdom did. And now I’m going to pull you up by the roots.

18.verse: The Plot To Kill Jeremiah - Some people plotted to kill me. And like a lamb being led to the butcher, I knew nothing about their plans.

19.verse: But then the LORD told me that they had planned to chop me down like a tree— fruit and all— so that no one would ever remember me again.

20.verse: I prayed, “LORD All-Powerful, you always do what is right, and you know every thought. So I trust you to help me and to take revenge.”

21.verse: Then the LORD said: Jeremiah, some men from Anathoth say they will kill you, if you keep on speaking for me.

22.verse: But I will punish them. Their young men will die in battle, and their children will starve to death.

23.verse: And when I am finished, no one from their families will be left alive.

1.verse: Jeremiah Complains to the LORD - Whenever I complain to you, LORD, you are always fair. But now I have questions about your justice. Why is life easy for sinners? Why are they successful?

2.verse: You plant them like trees; you let them prosper and produce fruit. Yet even when they praise you, they don’t mean it.

3.verse: But you know, LORD, how faithful I’ve always been, even in my thoughts. So drag my enemies away and butcher them like sheep!

4.verse: How long will the ground be dry and the pasturelands parched? The birds and animals are dead and gone. And all of this happened because the people are so sinful. They even brag, “God can’t see the sins we commit.”

5.verse: The LORD Answers Jeremiah - Jeremiah, if you get tired in a race against people, how can you possibly run against horses? If you fall in open fields, what will happen in the forest along the Jordan River?

6.verse: Even your own family has turned against you. They act friendly, but don’t trust them. They’re out to get you, and so is everyone else.

7.verse: The LORD Is Furious with His People - I loved my people and chose them as my very own. But now I will reject them and hand them over to their enemies.

8.verse: My people have turned against me and roar at me like lions. That’s why I hate them.

9.verse: My people are like a hawk surrounded and attacked by other hawks. Tell the wild animals to come and eat their fill.

10.verse: My beautiful land is ruined like a field or a vineyard trampled by shepherds and stripped bare by their flocks.

11.verse: Every field I see lies barren, and no one cares.

12.verse: A destroying army marches along desert roads and attacks everywhere. They are my deadly sword; no one is safe from them.

13.verse: My people, you planted wheat, but because I was furious, I let only weeds grow. You wore yourselves out for nothing!

14.verse: The LORD Will Have Pity on Other Nations - The LORD said: I gave this land to my people Israel, but enemies around it have attacked and robbed it. So I will uproot them from their own countries just as I will uproot Judah from its land.

15.verse: But later, I will have pity on these nations and bring them back to their own lands.

16.verse: They once taught my people to worship Baal. But if they admit I am the only true God, and if they let my people teach them how to worship me, these nations will also become my people.

17.verse: However, if they don’t listen to me, I will uproot them from their lands and completely destroy them. I, the LORD, have spoken.

1.verse: Jeremiah’s Linen Shorts - The LORD told me, “Go and buy a pair of linen shorts. Wear them for a while, but don’t wash them.”

2.verse: So I bought a pair of shorts and put them on.

3.verse: Then the LORD said,

4.verse: “Take off the shorts. Go to Parah and hide the shorts in a crack between some large rocks.”

5.verse: And that’s what I did.

6.verse: Some time later the LORD said, “Go back and get the shorts.”

7.verse: I went back and dug the shorts out of their hiding place, but the cloth had rotted, and the shorts were ruined.

8.verse: Then the LORD said:

9.verse: Jeremiah, I will use Babylonia to destroy the pride of the people of Judah and Jerusalem.

10.verse: The people of Judah are evil and stubborn. So instead of listening to me, they do whatever they want and even worship other gods. When I am finished with these people, they will be good for nothing, just like this pair of shorts.

11.verse: These shorts were tight around your waist, and that’s how tightly I held onto the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. I wanted them to be my people. I wanted to make them famous, so that other nations would praise and honor me, but they refused to obey me.

12.verse: Wine Jars - The LORD said: Jeremiah, tell the people of Judah, “The LORD God of Israel orders you to fill your wine jars with wine.” They will answer, “Of course we fill our wine jars with wine! Why are you telling us something we already know?”

13.verse: Then say to them: I am the LORD, and what I’m going to do will make everyone in Judah and Jerusalem appear to be full of wine. And the worst ones will be the kings of David’s family and the priests and the prophets.

14.verse: Then I will smash them against each other like jars. I will have no pity on the young or the old, and they will all be destroyed. I, the LORD, have spoken.

15.verse: The People of Judah Will Be Taken Away - People of Judah, don’t be too proud to listen to what the LORD has said.

16.verse: You hope for light, but God is sending darkness. Evening shadows already deepen in the hills. So return to God and confess your sins to him before you trip and fall.

17.verse: If you are too proud to listen, I will weep alone. Tears will stream from my eyes when the LORD’s people are taken away as prisoners.

18.verse: The LORD told me to tell you that your king and his mother must surrender their thrones and remove their crowns.

19.verse: The cities in the Southern Desert are surrounded; no one can get in or out. Everyone in Judah will be taken away.

20.verse: Jerusalem, you were so proud of ruling the people of Judah. But where are they now? Look north, and you will see your enemies approaching.

21.verse: You once trusted them to help, but now I’ll let them rule you. What do you say about that? You will be in pain like a woman giving birth.

22.verse: Do you know why your clothes were torn off and you were abused? It was because of your terrible sins.

23.verse: Can you ever change and do what’s right? Can people change the color of their skin, or can a leopard remove its spots? If so, then maybe you can change and learn to do right.

24.verse: I will scatter you, just as the desert wind blows husks from grain tossed in the air.

25.verse: I won’t change my mind. I, the LORD, have spoken. You rejected me and worshiped false gods.

26.verse: You were married to me, but you were unfaithful. You even became a prostitute by worshiping disgusting gods on hilltops and in fields.

27.verse: So I’ll rip off your clothes and leave you naked and ashamed for everyone to see. You are doomed! Will you ever be worthy to worship me again?

1.verse: The Land Dries Up - When there had been no rain for a long time, the LORD told me to say to the people:

2.verse: Judah and Jerusalem weep as the land dries up.

3.verse: Rulers send their servants to the storage pits for water. But there’s none to be found; they return in despair with their jars still empty.

4.verse: There has been no rain, and farmers feel sick as they watch cracks appear in the dry ground.

5.verse: A deer gives birth in a field, then abandons her newborn fawn and leaves in search of grass.

6.verse: Wild donkeys go blind from starvation. So they stand on barren hilltops and sniff the air, hoping to smell green grass.

7.verse: The LORD’s People Pray - Our terrible sins may demand that we be punished. But if you rescue us, LORD, everyone will see how great you are.

8.verse: You’re our only hope; you alone can save us now. You help us one day, but you’re gone the next.

9.verse: Did this disaster take you by surprise? Are you a warrior with your hands tied? You have chosen us, and your temple is here. Don’t abandon us!

10.verse: The LORD’s Answer - My people, you love to wander away; you don’t even try to stay close to me. So now I will reject you and punish you for your sins. I, the LORD, have spoken.

11.verse: Lying Prophets - The LORD said, “Jeremiah, don’t ask me to help these people.

12.verse: They may even go without eating and offer sacrifices to please me and to give thanks. But when they cry out for my help, I won’t listen, and I won’t accept their sacrifices. Instead, I’ll send war, starvation, and disease to wipe them out.”

13.verse: I replied, “The other prophets keep telling everyone that you won’t send starvation or war, and that you’re going to give us peace.”

14.verse: The LORD answered: They claim to speak for me, but they’re lying! I didn’t even speak to them, much less choose them to be my prophets. Their messages come from worthless dreams, useless fortunetelling, and their own imaginations.

15.verse: Those lying prophets say there will be peace and plenty of food. But I say that those same prophets will die from war and hunger.

16.verse: And everyone who listens to them will be killed, just as they deserve. Their dead bodies will be thrown out into the streets of Jerusalem, because their families will also be dead, and no one will be left to bury them.

17.verse: Jeremiah, go and tell the people how you feel about all this. So I told them: “Tears will flood my eyes both day and night, because my nation suffers from a deadly wound.

18.verse: In the fields I see the bodies of those killed in battle. And in the towns I see crowds dying of hunger. But the prophets and priests go about their business, without understanding what has happened.”

19.verse: Jeremiah Prays to the LORD - Have you rejected Judah, LORD? Do you hate Jerusalem? Why did you strike down Judah with a fatal wound? We had hoped for peace and a time of healing, but all we got was terror.

20.verse: We and our ancestors are guilty of rebelling against you.

21.verse: If you save us, it will show how great you are. Don’t let our enemies disgrace your temple, your beautiful throne. Don’t forget that you promised to rescue us.

22.verse: Idols can’t send rain, and showers don’t fall by themselves. Only you control the rain, so we put our trust in you, the LORD our God.

1.verse: The People of Judah Will Die - The LORD said to me: Even if Moses and Samuel were here, praying with you, I wouldn’t change my mind. So send the people of Judah away.

2.verse: And when they ask where they are going, tell them that I, the LORD, have said: Some of you are going to die of horrible diseases. Others are going to die in war or from starvation. The rest will be led away to a foreign country.

3.verse: I will punish you in four different ways: You will be killed in war and your bodies dragged off by dogs, your flesh will be eaten by birds, and your bones will be chewed on by wild animals.

4.verse: This punishment will happen because of the horrible things your King Manasseh did. And you will be disgusting to all nations on earth.

5.verse: People of Jerusalem, who will feel sorry for you? Will anyone bother to ask if you are well?

6.verse: My people, you abandoned me and walked away. I am tired of showing mercy; that’s why I’ll destroy you

7.verse: by scattering you like straw blown by the wind. I will punish you with sorrow and death, because you refuse to change your ways.

8.verse: There will be more widows in Judah than grains of sand on a beach. A surprise attack at noon! And the mothers in Jerusalem mourn for their children.

9.verse: A mother is in deep despair and struggles for breath. Her daylight has turned to darkness— she has suffered the loss of her seven sons. I will kill anyone who survives. I, the LORD, have spoken.

10.verse: Jeremiah Complains - I wish I had never been born! I’m always in trouble with everyone in Judah. I never lend or borrow money, but everyone curses me just the same.

11.verse: Then the LORD replied, “I promise to protect you, and when disaster comes, even your enemies will beg you for help.”

12.verse: The Enemy Cannot Be Defeated - The LORD told me to say: People of Judah, just as you can’t break iron mixed with bronze, you can’t defeat the enemies that will attack from the north.

13.verse: I will give them everything you own, because you have sinned everywhere in your country.

14.verse: My anger is a fire that cannot be put out, so I will make you slaves of your enemies in a foreign land.

15.verse: Jeremiah Complains Again - You can see how I suffer insult after insult, all because of you, LORD. Don’t be so patient with my enemies; take revenge on them before they kill me.

16.verse: When you spoke to me, I was glad to obey, because I belong to you, the LORD All-Powerful.

17.verse: I don’t go to parties and have a good time. Instead, I keep to myself, because you have filled me with your anger.

18.verse: I am badly injured and in constant pain. Are you going to disappoint me, like a stream that goes dry in the heat of summer?

19.verse: The LORD Replies - Then the LORD told me: Stop talking like a fool! If you turn back to me and speak my message, I will let you be my prophet once again. I hope the people of Judah will accept what you say. But you can ignore their threats,

20.verse: because I am making you strong, like a bronze wall. They are evil and violent, but when they attack,

21.verse: I will be there to rescue you. I, the LORD, have spoken.

1.verse: Jeremiah Must Live His Message - The LORD said to me:

2.verse: Jeremiah, don’t get married and have children—Judah is no place to raise a family.

3.verse: I’ll tell you what’s going to happen to children and their parents here.

4.verse: They will die of horrible diseases and of war and starvation. No one will give them a funeral or bury them, and their bodies will be food for the birds and wild animals. And what’s left will lie on the ground like manure.

5.verse: When someone dies, don’t visit the family or show any sorrow. I will no longer love or bless or have any pity on the people of Judah.

6.verse: Rich and poor alike will die and be left unburied. No one will mourn and show their sorrow by cutting themselves or shaving their heads.

7.verse: No one will bring food and wine to help comfort those who are mourning the death of their father or mother.

8.verse: Don’t even set foot in a house where there is eating and drinking and celebrating.

9.verse: Warn the people of Judah that I, the LORD All-Powerful, will put an end to all their parties and wedding celebrations.

10.verse: They will ask, “Why has the LORD our God threatened us with so many disasters? Have we done something wrong or sinned against him?”

11.verse: Then tell them I have said: People of Judah, your ancestors turned away from me; they rejected my laws and teachings and started worshiping other gods.

12.verse: And you have done even worse! You are stubborn, and instead of obeying me, you do whatever evil comes to your mind.

13.verse: So I will throw you into a land that you and your ancestors know nothing about, a place where you will have to worship other gods both day and night. And I won’t feel the least bit sorry for you.

14.verse: A time will come when you will again worship me. But you will no longer call me the Living God who rescued Israel from Egypt.

15.verse: Instead, you will call me the Living God who rescued you from that country in the north and from the other countries where I had forced you to go. Someday I will bring you back to this land that I gave your ancestors.

16.verse: But for now, I am sending enemies who will catch you like fish and hunt you down like wild animals in the hills and the caves.

17.verse: I can see everything you are doing, even if you try to hide your sins from me.

18.verse: I will punish you double for your sins, because you have made my own land disgusting. You have filled it with lifeless idols that remind me of dead bodies.

19.verse: The LORD Gives Strength - I prayed to the LORD: Our LORD, you are the one who gives me strength and protects me like a fortress when I am in trouble. People will come to you from distant nations and say, “Our ancestors worshiped false and useless gods,

20.verse: worthless idols made by human hands.”

21.verse: Then the LORD replied, “That’s why I will teach them about my power, and they will know that I am the true God.”

1.verse: The LORD Will Punish Judah - The LORD said: People of Judah, your sins cannot be erased. They are written on your hearts like words chiseled in stone or carved on the corners of your altars.

2.verse: One generation after another has set up pagan altars and worshiped the goddess Asherah everywhere in your country— on hills and mountains, and under large trees.

3.verse: So I’ll take everything you own, including your altars, and give it all to your enemies.

4.verse: You will lose the land that I gave you, and I will make you slaves in a foreign country, because you have made my anger blaze up like a fire that won’t stop burning.

5.verse: Trust the LORD - I, the LORD, have put a curse on those who turn from me and trust in human strength.

6.verse: They will dry up like a bush in salty desert soil, where nothing can grow.

7.verse: But I will bless those who trust me.

8.verse: They will be like trees growing beside a stream— trees with roots that reach down to the water, and with leaves that are always green. They bear fruit every year and are never worried by a lack of rain.

9.verse: You people of Judah are so deceitful that you even fool yourselves, and you can’t change.

10.verse: But I know your deeds and your thoughts, and I will make sure you get what you deserve.

11.verse: You cheated others, but everything you gained will fly away, like birds hatched from stolen eggs. Then you will discover what fools you are.

12.verse: Jeremiah Prays to the LORD - Our LORD, your temple is a glorious throne that has stood on a mountain from the beginning.

13.verse: You are a spring of water giving Israel life and hope. But if the people reject what you have told me, they will be swept away like words written in dust.

14.verse: You, LORD, are the one I praise. So heal me and rescue me! Then I will be completely well and perfectly safe.

15.verse: The people of Judah say to me, “Jeremiah, you claimed to tell us what the LORD has said. So why hasn’t it come true?”

16.verse: Our LORD, you chose me to care for your people, and that’s what I have done. You know everything I have said, and I have never once asked you to punish them.

17.verse: I trust you for protection in times of trouble, so don’t frighten me.

18.verse: Keep me from failure and disgrace, but make my enemies fail and be disgraced. Send destruction to make their worst fears come true.

19.verse: Resting on the Sabbath - The LORD said: Jeremiah, stand at each city gate in Jerusalem, including the one the king uses, and speak to him and everyone else. Tell them I have said: I am the LORD, so pay attention.

20.verse: Resting on the Sabbath - The LORD said: Jeremiah, stand at each city gate in Jerusalem, including the one the king uses, and speak to him and everyone else. Tell them I have said: I am the LORD, so pay attention.

21.verse: If you value your lives, don’t do any work on the Sabbath. Don’t carry anything through the city gates or through the door of your house, or anywhere else. Keep the Sabbath day sacred! I gave this command to your ancestors, but they were stubborn and refused to obey or to be corrected. But if you obey,

26.verse: and others will come here from the nearby villages, from the towns of Judah and Benjamin, from the hill country and the foothills to the west, and from the Southern Desert. They will bring sacrifices to please me and to give me thanks, as well as offerings of grain and incense.

1.verse: Jeremiah Goes to the Pottery Shop - The LORD told me,

2.verse: “Go to the pottery shop, and when you get there, I will tell you what to say to the people.”

3.verse: I went there and saw the potter making clay pots on his pottery wheel.

4.verse: And whenever the clay would not take the shape he wanted, he would change his mind and form it into some other shape.

5.verse: Then the LORD told me to say:

6.verse: People of Israel, I, the LORD, have power over you, just as a potter has power over clay.

7.verse: If I threaten to uproot and shatter an evil nation

8.verse: and that nation turns from its evil, I will change my mind.

9.verse: If I promise to make a nation strong,

10.verse: but its people start disobeying me and doing evil, then I will change my mind and not help them at all.

11.verse: So listen to me, people of Judah and Jerusalem! I have decided to strike you with disaster, and I won’t change my mind unless you stop sinning and start living right.

12.verse: But I know you won’t listen. You might as well answer, “We don’t care what you say. We have made plans to sin, and we are going to be stubborn and do what we want!”

13.verse: So I, the LORD, command you to ask the nations, and find out if they have ever heard of such a horrible sin as what you have done.

14.verse: The snow on Lebanon’s mountains never melts away, and the streams there never run dry.

15.verse: But you, my people, have turned from me to burn incense to worthless idols. You have left the ancient road to follow an unknown path where you stumble over idols.

16.verse: Your land will be ruined, and every passerby will look at it with horror and make insulting remarks.

17.verse: When your enemies attack, I will scatter you like dust blown by an eastern wind. Then, on that day of disaster, I will turn my back on you.

18.verse: The Plot against Jeremiah - Some of the people said, “Let’s get rid of Jeremiah! We will always have priests to teach us God’s laws, as well as wise people to give us advice, and prophets to speak the LORD’s messages. So, instead of listening to Jeremiah any longer, let’s accuse him of a crime.”

19.verse: Jeremiah Prays about His Enemies - Please, LORD, answer my prayer. Make my enemies stop accusing me of evil.

20.verse: I tried to help them, but they are paying me back by digging a pit to trap me. I even begged you not to punish them.

21.verse: But now I am asking you to let their children starve or be killed in war. Let women lose their husbands and sons to disease and violence.

22.verse: These people have dug pits and set traps for me, LORD. Make them scream in fear when you send enemy troops to attack their homes.

23.verse: You know they plan to kill me. So get angry and punish them! Don’t ever forgive their terrible crimes.

1.verse: Jeremiah and the Clay Jar - The LORD said: Jeremiah, go to the pottery shop and buy a clay jar. Then take along some of the city officials and leading priests

2.verse: and go to Hinnom Valley, just outside Potsherd Gate. Tell the people that I have said:

3.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, and you kings of Judah and you people of Jerusalem had better pay attention. I am going to bring so much trouble on this valley that everyone who hears about it will be shocked.

4.verse: The people of Judah stopped worshiping me and made this valley into a place of worship for Baal and other gods that have never helped them or their ancestors or their kings. And they have committed murder here, burning their young, innocent children as sacrifices to Baal. I have never even thought of telling you to do that.

5.verse: The people of Judah stopped worshiping me and made this valley into a place of worship for Baal and other gods that have never helped them or their ancestors or their kings. And they have committed murder here, burning their young, innocent children as sacrifices to Baal. I have never even thought of telling you to do that.

6.verse: So watch out! Someday this place will no longer be called Topheth or Hinnom Valley. It will be called Slaughter Valley!

7.verse: You people of Judah and Jerusalem may have big plans, but here in this valley I’ll ruin those plans. I’ll let your enemies kill you, and I’ll tell the birds and wild animals to eat your dead bodies.

8.verse: I will turn Jerusalem into a pile of rubble, and every passerby will be shocked and horrified and will make insulting remarks.

9.verse: And while your enemies are trying to break through your city walls to kill you, the food supply will run out. You will become so hungry that you will eat the flesh of your friends and even of your own children.

10.verse: Jeremiah, as soon as you have said this, smash the jar while the people are watching.

11.verse: Then tell them that I have also said: I am the LORD All-Powerful, and I warn you that I will shatter Judah and Jerusalem just like this jar that is broken beyond repair. You will bury your dead here in Topheth, but so many of you will die that there won’t be enough room.

12.verse: I will make Jerusalem as unclean as Topheth, by filling the city with your dead bodies. I will do this because you and your kings have gone up to the roofs of your houses and burned incense to the stars in the sky, as though they were gods. And you have given sacrifices of wine to foreign gods.

13.verse: I will make Jerusalem as unclean as Topheth, by filling the city with your dead bodies. I will do this because you and your kings have gone up to the roofs of your houses and burned incense to the stars in the sky, as though they were gods. And you have given sacrifices of wine to foreign gods.

14.verse: Jeremiah Speaks in the Temple Courtyard - I went to Topheth, where I told the people what the LORD had said. Then I went to the temple courtyard and shouted to the people,

15.verse: “Listen, everyone! Some time ago, the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, warned you that he would bring disaster on Jerusalem and all nearby villages. But you were stubborn and refused to listen. Now the LORD is going to bring the disaster he promised.”

1.verse: Pashhur Arrests Jeremiah - Pashhur son of Immer was a priest and the chief of temple security. He heard what I had said,

2.verse: and so he hit me. Then he had me arrested and put in chains at the Benjamin Gate in the LORD’s temple.

3.verse: The next day, when Pashhur let me go free, I told him that the LORD had said: No longer will I call you Pashhur. Instead, I will call you Afraid-of-Everything.

4.verse: You will be afraid, and you will bring fear to your friends as well. You will see enemies kill them in battle. Then I will have the king of Babylonia take everyone in Judah prisoner, killing some and dragging the rest away to Babylonia.

5.verse: He will clean out the royal treasury and take everything else of value from Jerusalem.

6.verse: Pashhur, you are guilty of telling lies and claiming they were messages from me. That’s why I will have the Babylonians take you, your family, and your friends as prisoners to Babylonia, where you will all die and be buried.

7.verse: Jeremiah Complains to the LORD - You tricked me, LORD, and I was really fooled. You are stronger than I am, and you have defeated me. People never stop sneering and insulting me.

8.verse: You have let me announce only destruction and death. Your message has brought me nothing but insults and trouble.

9.verse: Sometimes I tell myself not to think about you, LORD, or even mention your name. But your message burns in my heart and bones, and I cannot keep silent.

10.verse: I heard the crowds whisper, “Everyone is afraid. Now’s our chance to accuse Jeremiah!” All of my so-called friends are just waiting for me to make a mistake. They say, “Maybe Jeremiah can be tricked. Then we can overpower him and get even at last.”

11.verse: But you, LORD, are a mighty soldier, standing at my side. Those troublemakers will fall down and fail— terribly embarrassed, forever ashamed.

12.verse: LORD All-Powerful, you test those who do right, and you know every heart and mind. I have told you my complaints, so let me watch you take revenge on my enemies.

13.verse: I sing praises to you, LORD. You rescue the oppressed from the wicked.

14.verse: Put a curse on the day I was born! Don’t bless my mother.

15.verse: Put a curse on the man who told my father, “Good news! You have a son.”

16.verse: May that man be like the towns you destroyed without pity. Let him hear shouts of alarm in the morning and battle cries at noon.

17.verse: He deserves to die for not killing me before I was born. Then my mother’s body would have been my grave.

18.verse: Why did I have to be born? Was it just to suffer and die in shame?

1.verse: The LORD Will Fight against Jerusalem - King Zedekiah of Judah sent for Pashhur son of Malchiah and for a priest named Zephaniah son of Maaseiah. Then he told them,”Talk with Jeremiah for me.” So they came to me and said,

2.verse: “King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia has attacked Judah. Please ask the LORD to work miracles for our people, as he has done in the past, so that Nebuchadnezzar will leave us alone.”

3.verse: I told them that the LORD God of Israel had told me to say to King Zedekiah: The Babylonians have surrounded Jerusalem and want to kill you and your people. You are asking me to save you, but you have made me furious. So I will stretch out my mighty arm and fight against you myself. Your army is using spears and swords to fight the Babylonians, but I will make your own weapons turn and attack you. I will send a horrible disease to kill many of the people and animals in Jerusalem, and there will be nothing left to eat. Finally, I will let King Nebuchadnezzar and his army fight their way to the center of Jerusalem and capture everyone who is left alive, including you and your officials. But Nebuchadnezzar won’t be kind or show any mercy—he will have you killed! I, the LORD, have spoken.

9.verse: The Babylonian army has surrounded Jerusalem, so if you want to live, you must go out and surrender to them. But if you want to die because of hunger, disease, or war, then stay here in the city.

10.verse: I have decided not to rescue Jerusalem. Instead, I am going to let the king of Babylonia burn it to the ground. I, the LORD, have spoken.

11.verse: The LORD Warns the King of Judah - Pay attention, you that belong to the royal family.

12.verse: Each new day, make sure that justice is done, and rescue those who are being robbed. Or else my anger will flame up like a fire that never goes out.

13.verse: Jerusalem, from your mountaintop you look out over the valleys and think you are safe. But I, the LORD, am angry,

14.verse: and I will punish you as you deserve. I’ll set your palace on fire, and everything around you will go up in smoke.

1.verse: The LORD Will Punish the King of Judah - The LORD sent me to the palace of the king of Judah to speak to the king, his officials, and everyone else who was there. The LORD told me to say: I am the LORD, so pay attention! You have been allowing people to cheat, rob, and take advantage of widows, orphans, and foreigners who live here. Innocent people have become victims of violence, and some of them have even been killed. But now I command you to do what is right and see that justice is done. Rescue everyone who has suffered from injustice.
