The LORD told me to say: I am the LORD, so pay attention! You have been allowing people to cheat, rob, and take advantage of widows, orphans, and foreigners who live here. Innocent people have become victims of violence, and some of them have even been killed. But now I command you to do what is right and see that justice is done. Rescue everyone who has suffered from injustice.

4.verse: If you obey me, the kings from David’s family will continue to rule Judah from this palace. They and their officials will ride in and out on their horses or in their chariots.

5.verse: But if you ignore me, I promise in my own name that this palace will lie in ruins.

6.verse: Listen to what I think about it: The palace of Judah’s king is as glorious as Gilead or Lebanon’s highest peaks. But it will be as empty as a ghost-town when I’m through with it.

7.verse: I’ll send troops to tear it apart, and its beautiful cedar beams will be used for firewood.

8.verse: People from different nations will pass by and ask, “Why did the LORD do this to such a great city as Jerusalem?”

9.verse: Others will answer, “It’s because the people worshiped foreign gods and broke the agreement that the LORD their God had made with them.”

10.verse: King Jehoahaz - The LORD said: King Josiah is dead, so don’t cry for him. Instead, cry for his son King Jehoahaz, dragged off to another country, never to return.

11.verse: Jehoahaz became king of Judah after his father King Josiah died. But Jehoahaz was taken as a prisoner to a foreign country. Now I, the LORD, promise that he will die there without ever seeing his own land again.

12.verse: Jehoahaz became king of Judah after his father King Josiah died. But Jehoahaz was taken as a prisoner to a foreign country. Now I, the LORD, promise that he will die there without ever seeing his own land again.

13.verse: King Jehoiakim - The LORD told me to say: King Jehoiakim, you are doomed! You built a palace with large rooms upstairs.

14.verse: You put in big windows and used cedar paneling and red paint. But you were unfair and forced the builders to work without pay.

15.verse: More cedar in your palace doesn’t make you a better king than your father Josiah. He always did right— he gave justice to the poor and was honest.

16.verse: That’s what it means to truly know me. So he lived a comfortable life and always had enough to eat and drink.

17.verse: But all you think about is how to cheat or abuse or murder some innocent victim.

18.verse: Jehoiakim, no one will cry at your funeral. They won’t turn to each other and ask, “Why did our great king have to die?”

19.verse: You will be given a burial fit for a donkey; your body will be dragged outside the city gates and tossed in the dirt. I, the LORD, have spoken.

20.verse: King Jehoiachin and the People of Jerusalem - The LORD told me to say: People of Jerusalem, the nations you trusted have been crushed. Go to Lebanon and weep; cry in the land of Bashan and in Moab.

21.verse: When times were good, I warned you. But you ignored me, just as you have done since Israel was young.

22.verse: Now you will be disgraced because of your sins. Your leaders will be swept away by the wind, and the nations you trusted will be captured and dragged to a foreign country.

23.verse: Those who live in the palace paneled with cedar will groan with pain like women giving birth.

24.verse: King Jehoiachin, son of Jehoiakim, even if you were the ring I wear as the sign of my royal power, I would still pull you from my finger.

25.verse: I would hand you over to the enemy you fear, to King Nebuchadnezzar and his army, who want to kill you.

26.verse: You and your mother were born in Judah, but I will throw both of you into a foreign country, where you will die,

27.verse: longing to return home.

28.verse: Jehoiachin, you are unwanted like a broken clay pot. So you and your children will be thrown into a country you know nothing about.

29.verse: Land of Judah, I am the LORD. Now listen to what I say!

30.verse: Erase the names of Jehoiachin’s children from the royal records. He is a complete failure, and so none of them will ever be king. I, the LORD, have spoken.

1.verse: A Message of Hope - The LORD said: You leaders of my people are like shepherds that kill and scatter the sheep.

2.verse: You were supposed to take care of my people, but instead you chased them away. So now I’ll really take care of you, and believe me, you will pay for your crimes!

3.verse: I will bring the rest of my people home from the lands where I have scattered them, and they will grow into a mighty nation.

4.verse: I promise to choose leaders who will care for them like real shepherds. All of my people will be there, and they will never again be frightened.

5.verse: Someday I will appoint an honest king from the family of David, a king who will be wise and rule with justice.

6.verse: As long as he is king, Israel will have peace, and Judah will be safe. The name of this king will be “The LORD Gives Justice.”

7.verse: A time will come when you will again worship me. But you will no longer call me the Living God who rescued Israel from Egypt.

8.verse: Instead, you will call me the Living God who rescued you from the land in the north and from all the other countries where I had forced you to go. And you will once again live in your own land.

9.verse: Jeremiah Thinks about Unfaithful Prophets - When I think of the prophets, I am shocked, and I tremble like someone drunk, because of the LORD and his sacred words.

10.verse: Those unfaithful prophets misuse their power all over the country. So God turned the pasturelands into scorching deserts.

11.verse: The LORD Will Punish Unfaithful Prophets - The LORD told me to say: You prophets and priests think so little of me, the LORD, that you even sin in my own temple!

12.verse: Now I will punish you with disaster, and you will slip and fall in the darkness. I, the LORD, have spoken.

13.verse: The prophets in Samaria were disgusting to me, because they preached in the name of Baal and led my people astray.

14.verse: And you prophets in Jerusalem are even worse. You’re unfaithful in marriage and never tell the truth. You even lead others to sin instead of helping them turn back to me. You and the people of Jerusalem are evil like Sodom and Gomorrah.

15.verse: You prophets in Jerusalem have spread evil everywhere. That’s why I, the LORD, promise to give you bitter poison to eat and drink.

16.verse: The LORD Gives a Warning - The LORD said: Don’t listen to the lies of these false prophets, you people of Judah! The message they preach is something they imagined; it did not come from me, the LORD All-Powerful.

17.verse: These prophets go to people who refuse to respect me and who are stubborn and do whatever they want. The prophets tell them, “The LORD has promised everything will be fine.”

18.verse: But I, the LORD, tell you that these prophets have never attended a meeting of my council in heaven or heard me speak.

19.verse: They are evil! So in my anger I will strike them like a violent storm.

20.verse: I won’t calm down, until I have finished what I have decided to do. Someday you will understand exactly what I mean.

21.verse: I did not send these prophets or speak to them, but they ran to find you and to preach their message.

22.verse: If they had been in a meeting of my council in heaven, they would have told you people of Judah to give up your sins and come back to me.

23.verse: I am everywhere— both near and far,

24.verse: in heaven and on earth. There are no secret places where you can hide from me.

25.verse: These unfaithful prophets claim that I have given them a dream or a vision, and then they tell lies in my name.

26.verse: But everything they say comes from their own twisted minds. How long can this go on?

27.verse: They tell each other their dreams and try to get my people to reject me, just as their ancestors left me and worshiped Baal.

28.verse: Their dreams and my truth are as different as straw and wheat. But when prophets speak for me, they must say only what I have told them.

29.verse: My words are a powerful fire; they are a hammer that shatters rocks.

30.verse: These unfaithful prophets claim I give them their dreams, but it isn’t true. I didn’t choose them to be my prophets, and yet they babble on and on, speaking in my name, while stealing words from each other. And when my people hear these liars, they are led astray instead of being helped. So I warn you that I am now the enemy of these prophets. I, the LORD, have spoken.

33.verse: News and Nuisance - The LORD said to me: Jeremiah, when a prophet or a priest or anyone else comes to you and asks, “Does the LORD have news for us?” tell them, “You people are a nuisance to the LORD, and he will get rid of you.”

34.verse: If any of you say, “Here is news from the LORD,” I will punish you and your families, even if you are a prophet or a priest.

35.verse: Instead, you must ask your friends and relatives, “What answer did the LORD give?” or “What has the LORD said?”

36.verse: It seems that you each have your own news! So if you say, “Here is news from the LORD,” you are twisting my words into a lie. Remember that I am your God, the LORD All-Powerful.

37.verse: If you go to a prophet, it’s all right to ask, “What answer did the LORD give to my question?” or “What has the LORD said?”

38.verse: But if you disobey me and say, “Here is news from the LORD,”

39.verse: I will pick you up and throw you far away. And I will abandon this city of Jerusalem that I gave to your ancestors.

40.verse: You will never be free from your shame and disgrace.

1.verse: Jeremiah Has a Vision of Two Baskets of Figs - The LORD spoke to me in a vision after King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia had come to Judah and taken King Jehoiachin, his officials, and all the skilled workers back to Babylonia. In this vision I saw two baskets of figs in front of the LORD’s temple.

2.verse: One basket was full of very good figs that ripened early, and the other was full of rotten figs that were not fit to eat.

3.verse: “Jeremiah,” the LORD asked, “what do you see?” “Figs,” I said. “Some are very good, but the others are too rotten to eat.”

4.verse: Then the LORD told me to say:

5.verse: People of Judah, the good figs stand for those of you I sent away as exiles to Babylonia,

6.verse: where I am watching over them. Then someday I will bring them back to this land. I will plant them, instead of uprooting them, and I will build them up, rather than tearing them down.

7.verse: I will give them a desire to know me and to be my people. They will want me to be their God, and they will turn back to me with all their heart.

8.verse: The rotten figs stand for King Zedekiah of Judah, his officials, and all the others who were not taken away to Babylonia, whether they stayed here in Judah or went to live in Egypt.

9.verse: I will punish them with a terrible disaster, and everyone on earth will tremble when they hear about it. I will force the people of Judah to go to foreign countries, where they will be cursed and insulted.

10.verse: War and hunger and disease will strike them, until they finally disappear from the land that I gave them and their ancestors.

1.verse: Seventy Years of Exile - In the fourth year that Jehoiakim was king of Judah, which was the first year that Nebuchadnezzar was king of Babylonia, the LORD told me to speak to the people of Judah and Jerusalem. So I told them:

2.verse: Seventy Years of Exile - In the fourth year that Jehoiakim was king of Judah, which was the first year that Nebuchadnezzar was king of Babylonia, the LORD told me to speak to the people of Judah and Jerusalem. So I told them:

3.verse: For twenty-three years now, ever since the thirteenth year that Josiah was king, I have been telling you what the LORD has told me. But you have not listened.

4.verse: The LORD has sent prophets to you time after time, but you refused to listen.

5.verse: They told you that the LORD had said: Change your ways! If you stop doing evil, I will let you stay forever in this land that I gave your ancestors.

6.verse: I don’t want to harm you. So don’t make me angry by worshiping idols and other gods.

7.verse: But you refused to listen to my prophets. So I, the LORD, say that you have made me angry by worshiping idols, and you are the ones who were hurt by what you did.

8.verse: You refused to listen to me,

9.verse: and now I will let you be attacked by nations from the north, and especially by my servant, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia. You and other nearby nations will be destroyed and left in ruins forever. Everyone who sees what has happened will be shocked, but they will still make fun of you.

10.verse: I will put an end to your parties and wedding celebrations; no one will grind grain or be here to light the lamps at night.

11.verse: This country will be as empty as a desert, because I will make all of you the slaves of the king of Babylonia for seventy years.

12.verse: When that time is up, I will punish the king of Babylonia and his people for everything they have done wrong, and I will turn that country into a wasteland forever.

13.verse: My servant Jeremiah has told you what I said I will do to Babylonia and to the other nations, and he wrote it all down in this book. I will do everything I threatened.

14.verse: I will pay back the Babylonians for every wrong they have done. Great kings from many other nations will conquer the Babylonians and force them to be slaves.

15.verse: The Cup Full of God’s Anger - The LORD God of Israel showed me a vision in which he said, “Jeremiah, here is a cup filled with the wine of my anger. Take it and make every nation drink some.

16.verse: They will vomit and act crazy, because of the war this cup of anger will bring to them.”

17.verse: I took the cup from the LORD’s hand, and I went to the kings of the nations and made each of them drink some.

18.verse: I started with Jerusalem and the towns of Judah, and the king and his officials were removed from power in disgrace. Everyone still makes insulting jokes about them and uses their names as curse words.

19.verse: The second place I went was Egypt, where everyone had to drink from the cup, including the king and his officials, the other government workers, the rest of the Egyptians,

20.verse: and all the foreigners who lived in the country. Next I went to the king of Uz, and then to the four kings of Philistia, who ruled from Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and what was left of Ashdod.

21.verse: Then I went to the kings of Edom, Moab, Ammon,

22.verse: and to the kings of Tyre, Sidon, and their colonies across the sea.

23.verse: After this, I went to the kings of Dedan, Tema, Buz, the tribes of the Arabian Desert,

24.verse: After this, I went to the kings of Dedan, Tema, Buz, the tribes of the Arabian Desert,

25.verse: Zimri, Elam, Media,

26.verse: and the countries in the north, both near and far. I went to all the countries on earth, one after another, and finally to Babylonia.

27.verse: The LORD had said to tell each king, “The LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, commands you to drink from this cup that is full of the wine of his anger. It will make you so drunk that you will vomit. And when the LORD sends war against the nations, you will be completely defeated.”

28.verse: The LORD told me that if any of them refused to drink from the cup, I must tell them that he had said, “I, the LORD All-Powerful, command you to drink.

29.verse: Starting with my own city of Jerusalem, everyone on earth will suffer from war. So there is no way I will let you escape unharmed.”

30.verse: The LORD told me to say: From my sacred temple I will roar like thunder, while I trample my people and everyone else as though they were grapes.

31.verse: My voice will be heard everywhere on earth, accusing nations of their crimes and sentencing the guilty to death.

32.verse: Disaster Is Coming - The LORD All-Powerful says: You can see disaster spreading from far across the earth, from nation to nation like a horrible storm.

33.verse: When it strikes, I will kill so many people that their bodies will cover the ground like manure. No one will be left to bury them or to mourn.

34.verse: The Leaders of Judah Will Be Punished - The LORD’s people are his flock, and you leaders were the shepherds. But now it’s your turn to be butchered like sheep. You’ll shatter like fine pottery dropped on the floor. So roll on the ground, crying and mourning.

35.verse: You have nowhere to run, nowhere to hide.

36.verse: Listen to the cries of the shepherds,

37.verse: as the LORD’s burning anger turns peaceful meadows into barren deserts.

38.verse: The LORD has abandoned his people like a lion leaving its den.

2.verse: Jeremiah, I have a message for everyone who comes from the towns of Judah to worship in my temple. Go to the temple courtyard and speak every word that I tell you.

3.verse: Maybe the people will listen this time. And if they stop doing wrong, I will change my mind and not punish them for their sins.

4.verse: Tell them that I have said: You have refused to listen to me and to obey my laws and teachings.

5.verse: Again and again I have sent my servants the prophets to preach to you, but you ignored them as well. Now I am warning you that if you don’t start obeying me right away,

6.verse: I will destroy this temple, just as I destroyed the town of Shiloh. Then everyone on earth will use the name “Jerusalem” as a curse word.

7.verse: Jeremiah on Trial - The prophets, the priests, and everyone else in the temple heard what I said,

8.verse: and as soon as I finished, they all crowded around me and started shouting, “Why did you preach that the LORD will destroy this temple, just as he destroyed Shiloh? Why did you say that Jerusalem will be empty and lie in ruins? You ought to be put to death for saying such things in the LORD’s name!” Then they had me arrested.

11.verse: While they listened, the priests and the prophets said to the crowd, “All of you have heard Jeremiah prophesy that Jerusalem will be destroyed. He deserves the death penalty.”

12.verse: Then I told the judges and everyone else: The LORD himself sent me to tell you about the terrible things he will do to you, to Jerusalem, and to the temple. But if you change your ways and start obeying the LORD, he will change his mind.

13.verse: Then I told the judges and everyone else: The LORD himself sent me to tell you about the terrible things he will do to you, to Jerusalem, and to the temple. But if you change your ways and start obeying the LORD, he will change his mind.

14.verse: You must decide what to do with me. Just do whatever you think is right.

15.verse: But if you put me to death, you and everyone else in Jerusalem will be guilty of murdering an innocent man, because everything I preached came from the LORD.

16.verse: The judges and the other people told the priests and prophets, “Since Jeremiah only told us what the LORD our God had said, we don’t think he deserves to die.”

2.verse: Slaves of Nebuchadnezzar - Not long after Zedekiah became king of Judah, the LORD told me: Jeremiah, make a wooden yoke with leather straps, and place it on your neck.

3.verse: Then send a message to the kings of Edom, Moab, Ammon, Tyre, and Sidon. Some officials from these countries are in Jerusalem, meeting with Zedekiah.

4.verse: So have them tell their kings that I have said: I am the All-Powerful LORD God of Israel,

5.verse: and with my power I created the earth, its people, and all animals. I decide who will rule the earth,

6.verse: and I have chosen my servant King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia to rule all nations, including yours. I will even let him rule the wild animals. All nations will be slaves of Nebuchadnezzar, his son, and his grandson. Then many nations will join together, and their kings will be powerful enough to make slaves of the Babylonians.

7.verse: and I have chosen my servant King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia to rule all nations, including yours. I will even let him rule the wild animals. All nations will be slaves of Nebuchadnezzar, his son, and his grandson. Then many nations will join together, and their kings will be powerful enough to make slaves of the Babylonians.

8.verse: This yoke stands for the power of King Nebuchadnezzar, and I will destroy any nation that refuses to obey him. Nebuchadnezzar will attack, and many will die in battle or from hunger and disease.

9.verse: You might have people in your kingdom who claim they can tell the future by magic or by talking with the dead or by dreams or messages from a god. But don’t pay attention if any of them tell you not to obey Nebuchadnezzar.

10.verse: If you listen to such lies, I will have you dragged far from your country and killed.

11.verse: But if you and your nation are willing to obey Nebuchadnezzar, I will let you stay in your country, and your people will continue to live and work on their farms.

12.verse: After I had spoken to the officials from the nearby kingdoms, I went to King Zedekiah and told him the same thing. Then I said: Zedekiah, if you and the people of Judah want to stay alive, you must obey Nebuchadnezzar and the Babylonians.

13.verse: But if you refuse, then you and your people will die from war, hunger, and disease, just as the LORD has warned.

14.verse: Your prophets have told you that you don’t need to obey Nebuchadnezzar, but don’t listen to their lies.

15.verse: Those prophets claim to be speaking for the LORD, but he didn’t send them. They are lying! If you do what they say, he will have both you and them dragged off to another country and killed. The LORD has spoken.

16.verse: When I finished talking to the king, I went to the priests and told them that the LORD had said: Don’t listen to the prophets when they say that very soon the Babylonians will return the things they took from my temple. Those prophets are lying!

17.verse: If you choose to obey the king of Babylonia, you will live. But if you listen to those prophets, this whole city will be nothing but a pile of rubble.

1.verse: Jeremiah Accuses Hananiah of Being a False Prophet - Later that same year, in the fifth month of the fourth year that Zedekiah was king, the prophet Hananiah son of Azzur from Gibeon came up to me in the temple. And while the priests and others in the temple were listening,

2.verse: he told me that the LORD had said: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, and I will smash the yoke that Nebuchadnezzar put on the necks of the nations to make them his slaves.

3.verse: And within two years, I will bring back to Jerusalem everything that he took from my temple and carried off to Babylonia.

4.verse: King Jehoiachin and the other people who were taken from Judah to Babylonia will be allowed to come back here as well. All this will happen because I will smash the power of the king of Babylonia!

5.verse: The priests and the others were still standing there, so I said:

6.verse: Hananiah, I hope the LORD will do exactly what you said. I hope he does bring back everything the Babylonians took from the temple, and that our people who were taken to Babylonia will be allowed to return home.

7.verse: But let me remind you and everyone else

8.verse: that long before we were born, prophets were saying powerful kingdoms would be struck by war, disaster, and disease.

9.verse: Now you are saying we will have peace. We will just have to wait and see if that is really what the LORD has said.

10.verse: Hananiah grabbed the wooden yoke from my neck and smashed it.

11.verse: Then he said, “The LORD says this is the way he will smash the power Nebuchadnezzar has over the nations, and it will happen in less than two years.” I left the temple,

12.verse: and a little while later, the LORD told me

13.verse: to go back and say to Hananiah: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel. You smashed a wooden yoke, but I will replace it with one made of iron. I will put iron yokes on all the nations, and they will have to do what King Nebuchadnezzar commands. I will even let him rule the wild animals.

6.verse: Get married and have children, then help your sons find wives and help your daughters find husbands, so they can have children as well. I want your numbers to grow, not to get smaller.

7.verse: Pray for peace in Babylonia and work hard to make it prosperous. The more successful that nation is, the better off you will be.

26.verse: After the death of Jehoiada the priest, the LORD chose you to be the priest in charge of the temple security force. You know that anyone who acts crazy and pretends to be a prophet should be arrested and put in chains and iron collars.

27.verse: Jeremiah from the town of Anathoth is pretending to be a prophet there in Jerusalem, so why haven’t you punished him?

28.verse: He even wrote a letter to the people here in Babylonia, saying we would be here a long time. He told us to build homes and to plant gardens and grow our own food.

29.verse: When Zephaniah received Shemaiah’s letter, he read it to me.

31.verse: to the people of Judah who had been taken to Babylonia. In this letter, I wrote that the LORD had said: I, the LORD, have not chosen Shemaiah to be one of my prophets, and he has misled you by telling lies in my name.

1.verse: The LORD Will Rescue Israel and Judah - The LORD God of Israel said, “Jeremiah, get a scroll and write down everything I have told you.

2.verse: The LORD Will Rescue Israel and Judah - The LORD God of Israel said, “Jeremiah, get a scroll and write down everything I have told you.

3.verse: Someday I will let my people from both Israel and Judah return to the land I gave their ancestors.”

4.verse: Then the LORD told me to say to Israel and Judah: I, the LORD, hear screams of terror, and there is no peace.

5.verse: Then the LORD told me to say to Israel and Judah: I, the LORD, hear screams of terror, and there is no peace.

6.verse: Can men give birth? Then why do I see them looking so pale and clutching their stomachs like women in labor?

7.verse: My people, soon you will suffer worse than ever before, but I will save you.

8.verse: Now you are slaves of other nations, but I will break the chains and smash the yokes that keep you in slavery.

9.verse: Then you will be my servants, and I will choose a king for you from the family of David.

10.verse: Israel, you belong to me, so don’t be afraid. You deserved to be punished; that’s why I scattered you in distant nations. But I am with you, and someday I will destroy those nations.

11.verse: Then I will bring you and your descendants back to your land, where I will protect you and give you peace. Then your fears will be gone. I, the LORD, have spoken.

12.verse: The LORD Will Heal Israel and Judah - The LORD said: My people, you are wounded and near death.

13.verse: You are accused of a crime with no one to defend you, and you are covered with sores that no medicine can cure.

14.verse: Your friends have forgotten you; they don’t care anymore. Even I have acted like an enemy. And because your sins are horrible and countless, I will be cruel as I punish you.

15.verse: So don’t bother to cry out for relief from your pain.

16.verse: But if your enemies try to rob or destroy you, I will rob and destroy them, and they will be led as captives to foreign lands.

17.verse: No one wants you as a friend or cares what happens to you. But I will heal your injuries, and you will get well.

18.verse: The LORD Will Rescue Israel and Judah - The LORD said: Israel, I will be kind to you and let you come home. Jerusalem now lies in ruins, but you will rebuild it, complete with a new palace.

19.verse: Other nations will respect and honor you. Your homes will be filled with children, and you will celebrate, singing praises to me.

20.verse: It will be just like old times. Your nation will worship me, and I will punish anyone who abuses you.

21.verse: One of your own people will become your ruler. And when I invite him to come near me at the place of worship, he will do so. No one would dare to come near without being invited.

22.verse: You will be my people, and I will be your God. I, the LORD, have spoken.

23.verse: I am furious! And like a violent storm I will strike those who do wrong.

24.verse: I won’t calm down until I have finished what I have decided to do. Someday, you will understand what I mean.

1.verse: Israel Will Return to God - The LORD said: Israel, I promise that someday all your tribes will again be my people, and I will be your God.

2.verse: In the desert I was kind to those who escaped death. I gave them peace, and when the time is right, I’ll do the same for you. I, the LORD, have spoken.

3.verse: The LORD Will Rebuild Israel - Some time ago, the LORD appeared to me and told me to say: Israel, I will always love you; that’s why I’ve been so patient and kind.

4.verse: You are precious to me, and so I will rebuild your nation. Once again you will dance for joy and play your tambourines.

5.verse: You will plant vineyards on the hills of Samaria and enjoy the grapes.

6.verse: Someday those who guard the hill country of Ephraim will shout, “Let’s go to Zion and worship the LORD our God.”

7.verse: Israel Will Return to Its Own Land - The LORD says: Celebrate and sing for Israel, the greatest of nations. Offer praises and shout, “Come and rescue your people, LORD! Save what’s left of Israel.”

8.verse: I, the LORD, will bring my people back from Babylonia and everywhere else on earth. The blind and the lame will be there. Expectant mothers and women about to give birth will come and be part of that great crowd.

9.verse: They will weep and pray as I bring them home. I will lead them to streams of water. They will walk on a level road and not stumble. I am a father to Israel, my favorite children.

10.verse: Listen to me, you nations nearby or across the sea. I scattered the people of Israel, but I will gather them again. I will protect them like a shepherd guarding a flock;

11.verse: I will rescue them from enemies who could overpower them.

12.verse: My people will come to Mount Zion and celebrate; their faces will glow because of my blessings. I’ll give them grain, grapes, and olive oil, as well as sheep and cattle. Israel will be prosperous and grow like a garden with plenty of water.

13.verse: Young women and young men, together with the elderly, will celebrate and dance, because I will comfort them and turn their sorrow into happiness.

14.verse: I will bless my people with more food than they need, and the priests will enjoy the choice cuts of meat. I, the LORD, have spoken.

15.verse: The LORD Offers Hope - In Ramah a voice is heard, crying and weeping loudly. Rachel mourns for her children and refuses to be comforted, because they are dead.

16.verse: But I, the LORD, say to dry your tears. Someday your children will come home from the enemy’s land. Then all you have done for them will be greatly rewarded.

17.verse: So don’t lose hope. I, the LORD, have spoken.

18.verse: The people of Israel moan and say to me, “We were like wild bulls, but you, LORD, broke us, and we learned to obey. You are our God— please let us come home.

19.verse: When we were young, we strayed and sinned, but then we realized what we had done. We are ashamed and disgraced and want to return to you.”

20.verse: People of Israel, you are my own dear children. Don’t I love you best of all? Though I often make threats, I want you to be near me, so I will have mercy on you. I, the LORD, have spoken.

21.verse: With rock piles and signposts, mark the way home, my dear people. It is the same road by which you left.

22.verse: Will you ever decide to be faithful? I will make sure that someday things will be different, as different as a woman protecting a man.

23.verse: The LORD Will Bring Judah Home - The LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, said: I promise to set the people of Judah free and to lead them back to their hometowns. And when I do, they will once again say, “We pray that the LORD will bless his home, the sacred hill in Jerusalem where his temple stands.”

24.verse: The people will live in Jerusalem and in the towns of Judah. Some will be farmers, and others will be shepherds.

25.verse: Those who feel tired and worn out will find new life and energy,

26.verse: and when they sleep, they will wake up refreshed.

27.verse: Someday, Israel and Judah will be my field where my people and their livestock will grow.

28.verse: In the past, I took care to uproot them, to tear them down, and to destroy them. But when that day comes, I will take care to plant them and help them grow.

29.verse: No longer will anyone go around saying, “Sour grapes eaten by parents leave a sour taste in the mouths of their children.”

30.verse: When that day comes, only those who eat sour grapes will get the sour taste, and only those who sin will be put to death.

31.verse: The New Agreement with Israel and Judah - The LORD said: The time will surely come when I will make a new agreement with the people of Israel and Judah.

32.verse: It will be different from the agreement I made with their ancestors when I led them out of Egypt. Although I was their God, they broke that agreement.

33.verse: Here is the new agreement that I, the LORD, will make with the people of Israel: “I will write my laws on their hearts and minds. I will be their God, and they will be my people.

34.verse: “No longer will they have to teach one another to obey me. I, the LORD, promise that all of them will obey me, ordinary people and rulers alike. I will forgive their sins and forget the evil things they have done.”

35.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful. I command the sun to give light each day, the moon and stars to shine at night, and ocean waves to roar.

36.verse: I will never forget to give those commands, and I will never let Israel stop being a nation. I, the LORD, have spoken.

37.verse: Can you measure the heavens? Can you explore the depths of the earth? That’s how hard it would be for me to reject Israel forever, even though they have sinned. I, the LORD, have spoken.

38.verse: Jerusalem Will Be Rebuilt - The LORD said: Someday, Jerusalem will truly belong to me. It will be rebuilt with a boundary line running from Hananel Tower to Corner Gate.

39.verse: From there, the boundary will go in a straight line to Gareb Hill, then turn toward Goah.

40.verse: Even that disgusting Hinnom Valley will be sacred to me, and so will the eastern slopes that go down from Horse Gate into Kidron Valley. Jerusalem will never again be destroyed.

1.verse: Jeremiah Buys a Field - The LORD spoke to me in the tenth year that Zedekiah was king of Judah, which was the eighteenth year that Nebuchadnezzar was king of Babylonia.

2.verse: At that time, the Babylonian army had surrounded Jerusalem, and I was in the prison at the courtyard of the palace guards.

3.verse: Zedekiah had ordered me to be held there because I told everyone that the LORD had said: I am the LORD, and I am about to let the king of Babylonia conquer Jerusalem.

4.verse: King Zedekiah will be captured and taken to King Nebuchadnezzar, who will speak with him face to face.

5.verse: Then Zedekiah will be led away to Babylonia, where he will stay until I am finished with him. So, if you people of Judah fight against the Babylonians, you will lose. I, the LORD, have spoken.

6.verse: Later, when I was in prison, the LORD said:

7.verse: Jeremiah, your cousin Hanamel, the son of your uncle Shallum, will visit you. He must sell his field near the town of Anathoth, and because you are his nearest relative, you have the right and the responsibility to buy it and keep it in the family.

8.verse: Hanamel came, just as the LORD had promised. And he said, “Please buy my field near Anathoth in the territory of the Benjamin tribe. You have the right to buy it, and if you do, it will stay in our family.” The LORD had told me to buy it

9.verse: from Hanamel, and so I did. The price was seventeen pieces of silver, and I weighed out the full amount on a scale.

10.verse: I had two copies of the bill of sale written out, each containing all the details of our agreement. Some witnesses and I signed the official copy, which was folded and tied, before being sealed shut with hot wax. Then I gave Hanamel the silver.

11.verse: I had two copies of the bill of sale written out, each containing all the details of our agreement. Some witnesses and I signed the official copy, which was folded and tied, before being sealed shut with hot wax. Then I gave Hanamel the silver.

12.verse: And while he, the witnesses, and all the other Jews sitting in the courtyard were still watching, I gave both copies to Baruch son of Neriah.

13.verse: I told Baruch that the LORD had said: Take both copies of this bill of sale, one sealed shut and the other open, and put them in a clay jar so they will last a long time.

14.verse: I told Baruch that the LORD had said: Take both copies of this bill of sale, one sealed shut and the other open, and put them in a clay jar so they will last a long time.

15.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, and I promise you that people will once again buy and sell houses, farms, and vineyards in this country.

16.verse: Jeremiah Questions the LORD - Then I prayed:

17.verse: LORD God, you stretched out your mighty arm and made the sky and the earth. You can do anything.

18.verse: You show kindness for a thousand generations, but you also punish people for the sins of their parents. You are the LORD All-Powerful.

19.verse: With great wisdom you make plans, and with your great power you do all the mighty things you planned. Nothing we do is hidden from your eyes, and you reward or punish us as we deserve.

20.verse: You are famous because you worked miracles in Egypt, and you are still working them in Israel and in the rest of the world as well.

21.verse: You terrified the Egyptians with your miracles, and you reached out your mighty arm and rescued your people Israel from Egypt.

22.verse: Then you gave Israel this land rich with milk and honey, just as you had promised our ancestors.

23.verse: But when our ancestors took over the land, they did not obey you. And now you have punished Israel with disaster.

24.verse: Jerusalem is under attack, and we suffer from hunger and disease. The Babylonians have already built dirt ramps up to the city walls, and you can see that Jerusalem will be captured just as you said.

25.verse: So why did you tell me to get some witnesses and buy a field with my silver, when Jerusalem is about to be captured by the Babylonians?

26.verse: The LORD Explains about the Field - The LORD explained:

27.verse: Jeremiah, I am the LORD God. I rule the world, and I can do anything!

28.verse: It is true that I am going to let King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia capture Jerusalem.

29.verse: The Babylonian army is already attacking, and they will capture the city and set it on fire. The people of Jerusalem have made me angry by going up to the flat roofs of their houses and burning incense to Baal and offering wine sacrifices to other gods. Now these houses will be burned to the ground!

30.verse: The kings and the officials, the priests and the prophets, and everyone else in Israel and Judah have turned from me and made me angry by worshiping idols. Again and again I have tried to teach my people to obey me, but they refuse to be corrected. I am going to get rid of Jerusalem, because its people have done nothing but evil.

31.verse: The kings and the officials, the priests and the prophets, and everyone else in Israel and Judah have turned from me and made me angry by worshiping idols. Again and again I have tried to teach my people to obey me, but they refuse to be corrected. I am going to get rid of Jerusalem, because its people have done nothing but evil.

Again and again I have tried to teach my people to obey me, but they refuse to be corrected. I am going to get rid of Jerusalem, because its people have done nothing but evil.

Again and again I have tried to teach my people to obey me, but they refuse to be corrected. I am going to get rid of Jerusalem, because its people have done nothing but evil.

34.verse: They have set up disgusting idols in my temple, and now it isn’t a fit place to worship me.

35.verse: And they led Judah into sin by building places to worship Baal in Hinnom Valley, where they also sacrificed their sons and daughters to the god Molech. I have never even thought of telling them to commit such disgusting sins.

36.verse: Jeremiah, what you said is true. The people of Jerusalem are suffering from hunger and disease, and so the king of Babylonia will be able to capture Jerusalem.

37.verse: I am angry at the people of Jerusalem, and I will scatter them in foreign countries. But someday I will bring them back here and let them live in safety.

38.verse: They will be my people, and I will be their God.

39.verse: I will make their thoughts and desires pure. Then they will realize that, for their own good and the good of their children, they must worship only me. They will even be afraid to turn away from me. I will make an agreement with them that will never end, and I won’t ever stop doing good things for them. With all my heart I promise that they will be planted in this land once again.

42.verse: Even though I have brought disaster on the people, I will someday do all these good things for them.

43.verse: Jeremiah, when you bought the field, you showed that fields will someday be bought and sold again. You say that this land has been conquered by the Babylonians and has become a desert, emptied of people and animals.

44.verse: But someday, people will again spend their silver to buy fields everywhere—in the territory of Benjamin, the region around Jerusalem and the towns of Judah, and in the hill country, the foothills to the west, and the Southern Desert. Buyers and sellers and witnesses will sign and seal the bills of sale for the fields. It will happen, because I will give this land back to my people. I, the LORD, have spoken.

2.verse: The LORD Promises To Give the Land Back to His People - I was still being held prisoner in the courtyard of the palace guards when the LORD told me: I am the LORD, and I created the whole world.

3.verse: Ask me, and I will tell you things that you don’t know and can’t find out.

4.verse: Many of the houses in Jerusalem and some of the buildings at the royal palace have been torn down to be used in repairing the walls to keep out the Babylonian attackers. Now there are empty spaces where the buildings once stood. But I am furious, and these spaces will be filled with the bodies of the people I kill. The people of Jerusalem will cry out to me for help, but they are evil, and I will ignore their prayers.

7.verse: I will give this land to Israel and Judah once again, and I will make them as strong as they were before.

8.verse: They sinned and rebelled against me, but I will forgive them and take away their guilt.

9.verse: When that happens, all nations on earth will see the good things I have done for Jerusalem, and how I have given it complete peace. The nations will celebrate and praise and honor me, but they will also tremble with fear.

10.verse: Jeremiah, you say that this land is a desert without people or animals, and for now, you are right. The towns of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem are deserted, and people and animals are nowhere to be seen. But someday you will hear

11.verse: happy voices and the sounds of parties and wedding celebrations. And when people come to my temple to offer sacrifices to thank me, you will hear them say: “We praise you, LORD All-Powerful! You are good to us, and your love never fails.” The land will once again be productive.

12.verse: Now it is empty, without people or animals. But when that time comes, shepherds will take care of their flocks in pastures near every town in the hill country, in the foothills to the west, in the Southern Desert, in the land of the Benjamin tribe, and around Jerusalem and the towns of Judah. 14.verse: The LORD’s Wonderful Promise - The LORD said: I made a wonderful promise to Israel and Judah, and the days are coming when I will keep it.

15.verse: I promise that the time will come when I will appoint a king from the family of David, a king who will be honest and rule with justice.

16.verse: In those days, Judah will be safe; Jerusalem will have peace and will be named, “The LORD Gives Justice.”

17.verse: The king of Israel will be one of David’s descendants,

18.verse: and there will always be priests from the Levi tribe serving at my altar and offering sacrifices to please me and to give thanks.

19.verse: Then the LORD told me:

20.verse: I, the LORD, have an agreement with day and night, so they always come at the right time. You can’t break the agreement I made with them,

21.verse: and you can’t break the agreements I have made with David’s family and with the priests from the Levi tribe who serve at my altar. A descendant of David will always rule as king of Israel,

22.verse: and there will be more descendants of David and of the priests from the Levi tribe than stars in the sky or grains of sand on the beach.

23.verse: The LORD also said:

24.verse: You’ve heard foreigners insult my people by saying, “The LORD chose Israel and Judah, but now he has rejected them, and they are no longer a nation.”

25.verse: Jeremiah, I will never break my agreement with the day and the night or let the sky and the earth stop obeying my commands.

26.verse: In the same way, I will never reject the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob or break my promise that they will always have a descendant of David as their king. I will be kind to my people Israel, and they will be successful again.

1.verse: Jeremiah Warns Zedekiah - King Nebuchadnezzar had a large army made up of people from every kingdom in his empire. He and his army were attacking Jerusalem and all the nearby towns, when the LORD told me

2.verse: to say to King Zedekiah: I am the LORD, and I am going to let Nebuchadnezzar capture this city and burn it down.

3.verse: You will be taken prisoner and brought to Nebuchadnezzar, and he will speak with you face to face. Then you will be led away to Babylonia.

4.verse: Zedekiah, I promise that you won’t die in battle.

5.verse: You will die a peaceful death. People will mourn when you die, and they will light bonfires in your honor, just as they did for your ancestors, the kings who ruled before you.

6.verse: I went to Zedekiah and told him what the LORD had said.

7.verse: Meanwhile, the king of Babylonia was trying to break through the walls of Lachish, Azekah, and Jerusalem, the only three towns of Judah that had not been captured.

8.verse: The People Break a Promise - King Zedekiah, his officials, and everyone else in Jerusalem made an agreement to free all Hebrew men and women who were slaves. No Jew would keep another as a slave. And so, all the Jewish slaves were given their freedom.

13.verse: I am the LORD God of Israel, and I made an agreement with your ancestors when I brought them out of Egypt, where they had been slaves.

14.verse: As part of this agreement, you must let a Hebrew slave go free after six years of service. Your ancestors did not obey me,

15.verse: but you decided to obey me and do the right thing by setting your Hebrew slaves completely free. You even went to my temple, and in my name you made an agreement to set them free. But you have abused my name, because you broke your agreement and forced your former slaves back into slavery.

But you have abused my name, because you broke your agreement and forced your former slaves back into slavery.

17.verse: You have disobeyed me by not giving your slaves their freedom. So I will give you freedom—the freedom to die in battle or from disease or hunger. I will make you disgusting to all other nations on earth.

18.verse: You asked me to be a witness when you made the agreement to set your slaves free. And as part of the ceremony you cut a calf into two parts, then walked between the parts. But you people of Jerusalem have broken that agreement as well as my agreement with Israel. So I will do to you what you did to that calf.

19.verse: I will let your enemies take all of you prisoner, including the leaders of Judah and Jerusalem, the royal officials, the priests, and everyone else who walked between the two parts of the calf. These enemies will kill you and leave your bodies lying on the ground as food for birds and wild animals.

1.verse: Learn a Lesson from the Rechabites - When Jehoiakim was king of Judah, the LORD told me,

2.verse: “Go to the Rechabite clan and invite them to meet you in one of the side rooms of the temple. When they arrive, offer them a drink of wine.”

3.verse: So I went to Jaazaniah, the leader of the clan, and I invited him and all the men of his clan.

4.verse: I brought them into the temple courtyard and took them upstairs to a room belonging to the prophets who were followers of Hanan son of Igdaliah. It was next to a room belonging to some of the officials, and that room was over the one belonging to Maaseiah, a priest who was one of the high officials in the temple.

5.verse: I set out some large bowls full of wine together with some cups, and then I said to the Rechabites, “Have some wine!”

6.verse: But they answered: No! The ancestor of our clan, Jonadab son of Rechab, made a rule that we must obey. He said, “Don’t ever drink wine

7.verse: or build houses or plant crops and vineyards. Instead, you must always live in tents and move from place to place. If you obey this command, you will live a long time.”

18.verse: The LORD Makes a Promise to the Rechabites - Then the LORD told me to say to the Rechabite clan: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel. You have obeyed your ancestor Jonadab,

1.verse: King Jehoiakim Burns Jeremiah’s First Scroll - During the fourth year that Jehoiakim son of Josiah was king of Judah, the LORD said to me, “Jeremiah,

2.verse: since the time Josiah was king, I have been speaking to you about Israel, Judah, and the other nations. Now, get a scroll and write down everything I have told you,

3.verse: then read it to the people of Judah. Maybe they will stop sinning when they hear what terrible things I plan for them. And if they turn to me, I will forgive them.”

4.verse: I sent for Baruch son of Neriah and asked him to help me. I repeated everything the LORD had told me, and Baruch wrote it all down on a scroll.

5.verse: Then I said, Baruch, the officials refuse to let me go into the LORD’s temple,

6.verse: so you must go instead. Wait for the next holy day when the people of Judah come to the temple to pray and to go without eating. Then take this scroll to the temple and read it aloud.

7.verse: The LORD is furious, and if the people hear how he is going to punish them, maybe they will ask to be forgiven.

8.verse: In the ninth month of the fifth year that Jehoiakim was king, the leaders set a day when everyone who lived in Jerusalem or who was visiting here had to pray and go without eating. So Baruch took the scroll to the upper courtyard of the temple. He went over to the side of the courtyard and stood in a covered area near New Gate, where he read the scroll aloud. This covered area belonged to Gemariah, one of the king’s highest officials.

11.verse: Gemariah’s son Micaiah was there and heard Baruch read what the LORD had said.

12.verse: When Baruch finished reading, Micaiah went down to the palace. His father Gemariah was in the officials' room, meeting with the rest of the king’s officials, including Elishama, Delaiah, Elnathan, and Zedekiah.

13.verse: Micaiah told them what he had heard Baruch reading to the people.

14.verse: Then the officials sent Jehudi and Shelemiah to tell Baruch, “Bring us that scroll.” When Baruch arrived with the scroll,

15.verse: the officials said, “Please sit down and read it to us,” which he did.

16.verse: After they heard what was written on the scroll, they were worried and said to each other, “The king needs to hear this!” Turning to Baruch, they asked,

17.verse: “Did someone tell you what to write on this scroll?”

18.verse: “Yes, Jeremiah did,” Baruch replied. “I wrote down just what he told me.”

19.verse: The officials said, “You and Jeremiah must go into hiding, and don’t tell anyone where you are.”

20.verse: The officials put the scroll in Elishama’s room and went to see the king, who was in one of the rooms where he lived and worked during the winter. It was the ninth month of the year, so there was a fire burning in the fireplace, and the king was sitting nearby. After the officials told the king about the scroll, he sent Jehudi to get it. Then Jehudi started reading the scroll to the king and his officials.

32.verse: After the LORD finished speaking to me, I got another scroll and gave it to Baruch. Then I told him what to write, so this second scroll would contain even more than was on the scroll Jehoiakim had burned.

11.verse: Jeremiah Is Put in Prison - The Babylonian army had left because the Egyptian army was on its way to help us.

12.verse: So I decided to leave Jerusalem and go to the territory of the Benjamin tribe to claim my share of my family’s land.

13.verse: I was leaving Jerusalem through Benjamin Gate, when I was stopped by Irijah, the officer in charge of the soldiers at the gate. He said, “Jeremiah, you’re under arrest for trying to join the Babylonians.”

14.verse: “I’m not trying to join them!” I answered. But Irijah wouldn’t listen, and he took me to the king’s officials.

15.verse: They were angry and ordered the soldiers to beat me. Then I was taken to the house that belonged to Jonathan, one of the king’s officials. It had been turned into a prison, and I was kept in a basement room. After I had spent a long time there,

16.verse: They were angry and ordered the soldiers to beat me. Then I was taken to the house that belonged to Jonathan, one of the king’s officials. It had been turned into a prison, and I was kept in a basement room. After I had spent a long time there,

17.verse: King Zedekiah secretly had me brought to his palace, where he asked, “Is there any message for us from the LORD?” “Yes, there is, Your Majesty,” I replied. “The LORD is going to let the king of Babylonia capture you.”

18.verse: Then I continued, “Your Majesty, why have you put me in prison? Have I committed a crime against you or your officials or the nation?

19.verse: Have you locked up the prophets who lied to you and said that the king of Babylonia would never attack Jerusalem?

20.verse: Please, don’t send me back to that prison at Jonathan’s house. If you do, I will die.”

21.verse: King Zedekiah had me taken to the prison cells in the courtyard of the palace guards. He told the soldiers to give me a loaf of bread from one of the bakeries every day until the city ran out of grain.

1.verse: Jeremiah Is Held Prisoner in a Dry Well - One day, Shephatiah, Gedaliah, Jehucal, and Pashhur heard me tell the people of Judah

2.verse: that the LORD had said, “If you stay here in Jerusalem, you will die in battle or from disease or hunger, and the Babylonian army will capture the city anyway. But if you surrender to the Babylonians, they will let you live.”

3.verse: that the LORD had said, “If you stay here in Jerusalem, you will die in battle or from disease or hunger, and the Babylonian army will capture the city anyway. But if you surrender to the Babylonians, they will let you live.”

4.verse: So the four of them went to the king and said, “You should put Jeremiah to death, because he is making the soldiers and everyone else lose hope. He isn’t trying to help our people; he’s trying to harm them.”

5.verse: Zedekiah replied, “Do what you want with him. I can’t stop you.”

6.verse: Then they took me back to the courtyard of the palace guards and let me down with ropes into the well that belonged to Malchiah, the king’s son. There was no water in the well, and I sank down in the mud.

7.verse: Ebedmelech from Ethiopia was an official at the palace, and he heard what they had done to me. So he went to speak with King Zedekiah, who was holding court at Benjamin Gate.

8.verse: Ebedmelech from Ethiopia was an official at the palace, and he heard what they had done to me. So he went to speak with King Zedekiah, who was holding court at Benjamin Gate.

9.verse: Ebedmelech said, “Your Majesty, Jeremiah is a prophet, and those men were wrong to throw him into a well. And when Jerusalem runs out of food, Jeremiah will starve to death down there.”

10.verse: Zedekiah answered, “Take thirty of my soldiers and pull Jeremiah out before he dies.”

11.verse: Ebedmelech and the soldiers went to the palace and got some rags from the room under the treasury. He used ropes to lower them into the well.

12.verse: Then he said, “Put these rags under your arms so the ropes won’t hurt you.” After I did,

13.verse: the men pulled me out. And from then on, I was kept in the courtyard of the palace guards.

14.verse: King Zedekiah Questions Jeremiah - King Zedekiah had me brought to his private entrance to the temple, and he said, “I’m going to ask you something, and I want to know the truth.”

15.verse: “Why?” I replied. “You won’t listen, and you might even have me killed!”

16.verse: He said, “I swear in the name of the living LORD our Creator that I won’t have you killed. No one else can hear what we say, and I won’t let anyone kill you.”

17.verse: Then I told him that the LORD had said: “Zedekiah, I am the LORD God All-Powerful, the God of Israel. I promise that if you surrender to King Nebuchadnezzar’s officers, you and your family won’t be killed, and Jerusalem won’t be burned down.

18.verse: But if you don’t surrender, I will let the Babylonian army capture Jerusalem and burn it down, and you will be taken prisoner.”

19.verse: Zedekiah answered, “I can’t surrender to the Babylonians. I’m too afraid of the Jews that have already joined them. The Babylonians might hand me over to those Jews, and they would torture me.”

20.verse: I said, “If you will just obey the LORD, the Babylonians won’t hand you over to those Jews. You will be allowed to live, and all will go well for you.

21.verse: But the LORD has shown me that if you refuse to obey,

22.verse: then the women of your palace will be taken prisoner by Nebuchadnezzar’s officials. And those women will say to you: Friends you trusted led you astray. Now you’re trapped in mud, and those friends you trusted have all turned away.

23.verse: The Babylonian army will take your wives and children captive, you will be taken as a prisoner to the King of Babylonia, and Jerusalem will be burned down.”

24.verse: Zedekiah said, “Jeremiah, if you tell anyone what we have talked about, you might lose your life.

25.verse: And I’m sure that if my officials hear about our meeting, they will ask you what we said to each other. They might even threaten to kill you if you don’t tell them.

26.verse: So if they question you, tell them you were begging me not to send you back to the prison at Jonathan’s house, because going back there would kill you.”

27.verse: The officials did come and question me about my meeting with the king, and I told them exactly what he had ordered me to say. They never spoke to me about the meeting again, since no one had heard us talking.

28.verse: I was held in the courtyard of the palace guards until the day Jerusalem was captured.

5.verse: But the Babylonian troops caught up with them near Jericho. They arrested Zedekiah and took him to the town of Riblah in the land of Hamath, where Nebuchadnezzar put him on trial, then found him guilty

6.verse: and gave orders for him to be punished. Zedekiah’s sons were killed there in front of him, and so were the leaders of Judah’s ruling families.

7.verse: His eyes were poked out, and he was put in chains, so he could be dragged off to Babylonia.

8.verse: Meanwhile, the Babylonian army had burned the houses in Jerusalem, including the royal palace, and they had broken down the city walls.

9.verse: Nebuzaradan, the Babylonian officer in charge of the guards, led away everyone from the city as prisoners, even those who had deserted to Nebuchadnezzar.

10.verse: Only the poorest people who owned no land were left behind in Judah, and Nebuzaradan gave them fields and vineyards.

11.verse: Nebuchadnezzar had given the following orders to Nebuzaradan:

12.verse: “Find Jeremiah and keep him safe. Take good care of him and do whatever he asks.”

14.verse: sent some of their troops to bring me from the courtyard of the royal palace guards. They put me in the care of Gedaliah son of Ahikam and told him to take me to my home. And so I was allowed to stay with the people who remained in Judah.

16.verse: to Ebedmelech from Ethiopia: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel. I warned everyone that I would bring disaster, not prosperity, to this city. Now very soon I will do what I said, and you will see it happen.

17.verse: But because you trusted me, I will protect you from the officials of Judah, and when Judah is struck by disaster, I will rescue you and keep you alive. I, the LORD, have spoken.

1.verse: Jeremiah Is Set Free - I was led away in chains along with the people of Judah and Jerusalem who were being taken to Babylonia. Nebuzaradan was the officer in charge of the guard, and while we were stopped at Ramah, the LORD had him set me free.

2.verse: Nebuzaradan said: Jeremiah, the LORD your God warned your people that he would bring disaster on this land.

3.verse: But they continued to rebel against him, and now he has punished them just as he threatened.

4.verse: Today I am taking the chains off your wrists and setting you free! If you want to, you can come with me to Babylonia, and I will see that you are taken care of. Or if you decide to stay here, you can go wherever you wish.

5.verse: King Nebuchadnezzar has chosen Gedaliah to rule Judah. You can live near Gedaliah, and he will provide for you, or you can live anywhere else you want. Nebuzaradan gave me a supply of food, then let me leave.

6.verse: I decided to stay with the people of Judah, and I went to live near Gedaliah in Mizpah.

9.verse: Gedaliah told them, “There’s no need to be afraid of the Babylonians. Everything will be fine, if we live peacefully and obey King Nebuchadnezzar.

10.verse: I will stay here at Mizpah and meet with the Babylonian officials on each of their visits. But you must go back to your towns and bring in the harvest, then store the wine, olive oil, and dried fruit.”

11.verse: Earlier, when the Babylonians had invaded Judah, many of the Jews escaped to Moab, Ammon, Edom, and several other countries. But these Jews heard that the king of Babylonia had appointed Gedaliah as ruler of Judah, and that only a few people were left there. So the Jews in these other countries came back to Judah and helped with the grape and fruit harvest, which was especially large that year.

13.verse: Gedaliah Is Murdered - One day, Johanan got together with some of the other men who had been army officers, and they came to Mizpah and met with Gedaliah.

14.verse: They said, “Gedaliah, we came to warn you that King Baalis of Ammon hired Ishmael to murder you!” Gedaliah refused to believe them,

15.verse: so Johanan went to Gedaliah privately and said, “Let me kill Ishmael. No one will find out who did it. There are only a few people left in Judah, but they are depending on you. And if you are murdered, they will be scattered or killed.”

16.verse: Gedaliah answered, “Don’t kill Ishmael! What you’ve said about him can’t be true.”

1.verse: But in the seventh month, Ishmael came to Mizpah with ten of his soldiers. He had been one of the king’s officials and was a member of the royal family. Ishmael and his men were invited to eat with Gedaliah.

2.verse: During the meal, Ishmael and his soldiers killed Gedaliah, the man chosen as ruler of Judah by the king of Babylonia.

3.verse: Then they killed the Jews who were with Gedaliah, and they also killed the Babylonian soldiers who were there.

4.verse: The next day, the murders had still not been discovered,

5.verse: when eighty men came down the road toward Mizpah from the towns of Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria. They were on their way to the temple to offer gifts of grain and incense to the LORD. They had shaved off their beards, torn their clothes, and cut themselves, because they were mourning.

6.verse: Ishmael went out the town gate to meet them. He pretended to be weeping, and he asked them to come into Mizpah to meet with Gedaliah, the ruler of Judah.

7.verse: But after they were inside the town, Ishmael had his soldiers kill them and throw their bodies into a well.

8.verse: He let ten of the men live, because they offered to give him supplies of wheat, barley, olive oil, and honey they had hidden in a field.

9.verse: The well that he filled with bodies had been dug by King Asa of Judah to store rainwater, because he was afraid that King Baasha of Israel might surround Mizpah and keep the people from getting to their water supply.

10.verse: Nebuzaradan, King Nebuchadnezzar’s officer in charge of the guard, had left King Zedekiah’s daughters and many other people at Mizpah, and he had put Gedaliah in charge of them. But now Ishmael took them all prisoner and led them toward Ammon, on the other side of the Jordan River.

11.verse: Johanan and the other army officers heard what Ishmael had done.

12.verse: So they and their troops chased Ishmael and caught up with him at the large pit at Gibeon.

13.verse: When Ishmael’s prisoners saw Johanan and the officers, they were happy

14.verse: and turned around and ran toward Johanan.

15.verse: But Ishmael and eight of his men escaped and went to Ammon.

16.verse: Johanan Decides To Take the People to Egypt - Johanan and the officers had rescued the women, children, and royal officials that Ishmael had taken prisoner after killing Gedaliah. Johanan led the people from Gibeon

17.verse: toward Egypt. They wanted to go there, because they were afraid of what the Babylonians would do when they found out that Ishmael had killed Gedaliah, the ruler appointed by King Nebuchadnezzar. 1.verse: Johanan, Jezaniah, the other army officers, and everyone else in the group, came to me

2.verse: and said, “Please pray to the LORD your God for us. Judah used to have many people, but as you can see, only a few of us are left.

3.verse: Ask the LORD to tell us where he wants us to go and what he wants us to do.”

4.verse: “All right,” I answered, “I will pray to the LORD your God, and I will tell you everything he says.”

5.verse: They answered, “The LORD himself will be our witness that we promise to do whatever he says,

6.verse: even if it isn’t what we want to do. We will obey the LORD so that all will go well for us.”

7.verse: Ten days later, the LORD gave me an answer for

8.verse: Johanan, the officers, and the other people. So I called them together

9.verse: and told them that the LORD God of Israel had said: You asked Jeremiah to pray and find out what you should do.

10.verse: I am sorry that I had to punish you, and so I now tell you to stay here in Judah, where I will plant you and build you up, instead of tearing you down and uprooting you.

11.verse: Don’t be afraid of the King of Babylonia. I will protect you from him,

12.verse: and I will even force him to have mercy on you and give back your farms.

13.verse: But you might keep on saying, “We won’t stay here in Judah, and we won’t obey the LORD our God.

14.verse: We are going to Egypt, where there is plenty of food and no danger of war.”

15.verse: People of Judah, you survived when the Babylonian army attacked. Now you are planning to move to Egypt, and if you do go, this is what will happen.

16.verse: You are afraid of war, starvation, and disease here in Judah, but they will follow you to Egypt and kill you there. None of you will survive the disasters I will send.

17.verse: You are afraid of war, starvation, and disease here in Judah, but they will follow you to Egypt and kill you there. None of you will survive the disasters I will send.

18.verse: I, the LORD, was angry with the people of Jerusalem and punished them. And if you go to Egypt, I will be angry and punish you the same way. You will never again see your homeland. People will be horrified at what I do to you, and they will use the name of your city as a curse word.

19.verse: Jeremiah Gives a Warning - I told the people: You escaped the disaster that struck Judah, but now the LORD warns you to stay away from Egypt.

20.verse: You asked me to pray and find out what the LORD our God wants you to do, and you promised to obey him. But that was a terrible mistake,

21.verse: because now that I have given you the LORD’s answer, you refuse to obey him.

22.verse: And so, you will die in Egypt from war, hunger, and disease.

1.verse: The People Go to Egypt - I told the people everything the LORD had told me.

2.verse: But Azariah, Johanan and some other arrogant men said to me, “You’re lying! The LORD didn’t tell you to say that we shouldn’t go to Egypt.

3.verse: Baruch son of Neriah must have told you to say that. He wants the Babylonians to capture us, so they can take us away to Babylonia or even kill us.”

4.verse: Johanan, the other army officers, and everyone else refused to stay in Judah in spite of the LORD’s command.

5.verse: So Johanan and the officers led us away toward Egypt. The group that left Judah included those who had been scattered in other countries and who had then come back to live in Judah.

6.verse: Baruch and I and others in the group had been staying with Gedaliah, because Nebuzaradan, the Babylonian officer in charge of the guard, had ordered him to take care of the king’s daughters and quite a few men, women, and children.

7.verse: The people disobeyed the LORD and went to Egypt. The group had settled in Tahpanhes,

8.verse: when the LORD told me:

9.verse: Jeremiah, carry some large stones to the entrance of the government building in Tahpanhes. Bury the stones underneath the brick pavement and be sure the Jews are watching.

10.verse: Then tell them that I, the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, have sent for my servant, Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia. I will bring him here and have him set up his throne and his royal tent over these stones that I told you to bury.

11.verse: He will attack Egypt and kill many of its people; others will die of disease or be dragged away as prisoners.

12.verse: I will have him set Egypt’s temples on fire, and he will either burn or carry off their idols. He will destroy the sacred monuments at the temple of the sun-god. Then Nebuchadnezzar will pick the land clean, just like a shepherd picking the lice off his clothes. And he will return safely home.
